If there are a lot of these in order to distinguish these from the square brackets of the Tibetan refs, curly brackets will need to be used instead. since the @cRef attribute will automatically display square ones, the reference should be placed with in the node and the @cRef should not be used:
<ptid="81"> <refcRef="F.1.b"type="folio"/> <reftype="sanskrit">{S1}</ref> <reftype="chinese">{C1}</ref> I pay homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas. <!--...--> </p>
Example Note, there are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual <ref> to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's <bibl> element found in the TEI's initial <sourceDesc>. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's <sourceDesc>:
<teiHeader> <!--...--> <sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh193"type="text"> <ref>Toh 193</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a250.b</biblScope> <authorrole="translatorTib">Unknown</author> <locationcount-pages="10" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="500"number="61" start-page="491"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC14668"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC11815" work="W22084"/> </bibl> <biblkey="toh739"type="text"> <ref>Toh 739</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud bum, tsha), folios 230.a234.b</biblScope> <authorrole="translatorTib">Unknown</author> <locationcount-pages="10" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="468"number="94" start-page="459"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC21415"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC12480" work="W22084"/> </bibl> </sourceDesc> <!--...--> </teiHeader> <!--...--> <body> <!--...--> <ptid="9"> <refcRef="F.246.a"key="toh193" type="folio"/> <refcRef="F.230.a"key="toh739" type="folio"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. </p> <!--...--> </body>
Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa.
Example The <ref> element is also used to create links in the Reading Room to other 84000 published texts or other websites. The web address entered in to the value of the target attribute. Note that in-text links should not be made with <ref>s but with the <ptr> element instead. Any links to 84000 that are not yet published can be made with a coded comment <!--Reference Toh ####-->, which will be retrieved and applied when the future text is published. See Appendix Cross References and Links for more details.
<noteindex="586"place="end" xml:id="UT22084-055-001-1485"> Unidentified Indian musical instrument. It appears in two lists of instruments in the <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Lalitavistarastra</title> (see <titlexml:lang="en">The Play in Full</title> <reftarget="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-973">15.39</ref> <!--toh. 95--> and <reftarget="http://read.84000.co/translation/UT22084-046-001.html#UT22084-046-001-1001">15.67</ref> <!--toh. 95-->) with a stringed instrument preceding and following it, but some recent Tibetan-English dictionaries have cymbals.</note>
Example A single <ref> element is also entered into the source description <sourceDesc> in the TEI header, as a child of the <bibl> element to identify the Toh. number of the given text:
<sourceDesc> <bibl> <ref>Toh 194</ref> <biblScope> Deg Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 250.b 251.a</biblScope> <authorrole="translatorTib">Unknown</author> </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Schematron
<sch:reporttest="@target and @cRef">Only one of the attributes @target' and @cRef' may be supplied on <sch:name/> </sch:report>
Content model 
<content>
<macroRefkey="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element ref
{
   att.cReferencing.attributes,
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.attribute.xmlid,
   att.internetMedia.attributes,
   att.pointing.attributes,
   attribute rend { list { + } }?,
   attribute type { "bampo" | "sanskrit" | "chinese" | "volume" | "folio" }?,
   attribute key { text }?,
   attribute work { text }?,
   attribute page { text }?,
   attribute inst { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}

1.61. <row>

<row> (row) contains one row of a table. [14.1.1. TEI Tables]
Module figures
Attributes
role (role) indicates the kind of information held in this cell or in each cell of this row.
Derived from att.tableDecoration
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Suggested values include:
label
labelling or descriptive information only.
data
data values. [Default]
Contained by
figures: table
May contain
figures: cell
Note

Represents a particular row contained within a <table>. The row itself contains a series of <cell>s as they appear from left to right. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well.

For further details on tables see Appendix B Topics: Tables.

Example
<row> <cellrole="label">16163</cell> <cellrole="label">cakra</cell> <cell>secret</cell> <cell>navel</cell> <cell>heart</cell> <cell>throat</cell> <cell>forehead</cell> <cell>crown</cell> </row>
Content model 
<content>
<elementRefkey="cell"
maxOccurs="unbounded"minOccurs="1"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element row { attribute role { "label" | "data" }?, cell+ }

1.62. <sourceDesc>

<sourceDesc> (source description) describes the source(s) from which an electronic text was derived or generated, typically a bibliographic description in the case of a digitized text, or a phrase such as "born digital" for a text which has no previous existence. [2.2.7. The Source Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: biblScope p
derived-module-NewODD: link location
character data
Note

The <sourceDesc> is located in the TEI header and contains a single <bibl> element giving a description of the source text. All of this information will be displayed on the title page in the reading room.

Example
<sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh83"type="text"> <ref>Toh 83</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Deg Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a94a</citedRange--> <authorrole="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author> <authorrole="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author> <authorrole="translatorTib">Yesh D</author> <locationcount-pages="48" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="188"number="44" start-page="141"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC11626" work="W22084"/> </bibl> </sourceDesc>
Content model 
<content>textchaptertranslatorTibSa-LtnBo-LtnPi-LtnZh-LtnboenzhreviserSa-LtnBo-LtnPi-LtnZh-Ltnboenzh</content>
Schema Declaration 
element sourceDesc
{
   (
      element bibl
      {
         attribute key { string },
         attribute type { "text" | "chapter" },
         element ref { text, element extension { text }* },
         biblScope,
         element series { string }?,
         element citedRange { string }?,
         (
            element author
            {
               attribute role { "translatorTib" }?,
               attribute key { text }?,
               attribute ref { text }?,
               attribute xml:lang
               {
                  "Sa-Ltn"
                |"Bo-Ltn"
                |"Pi-Ltn"
                |"Zh-Ltn"
                |"bo"
                |"en"
                |"zh"
               }?,
               text
            }
          |element editor
            {
               attribute role { "reviser" }?,
               attribute ref { text }?,
               attribute revision { text }?,
               attribute xml:lang
               {
                  "Sa-Ltn"
                |"Bo-Ltn"
                |"Pi-Ltn"
                |"Zh-Ltn"
                |"bo"
                |"en"
                |"zh"
               }?,
               text
            }
         )*,
         location,
         element idno
         {
            attribute parent-id { text },
            attribute work { text }?
         },
         element idno { attribute source-id { text }, attribute work { text } }?
      }+
    |p
   ),
   link*
}

1.63. <space>

<space> Used to indicate that a quoted passage to another published 84000 TEI text has markup in the middle of the quote that needs to be ignored by the parser. See example in the layout checks 4.3.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Member of
endnote macro.paraContent macro.specialPara paragraph
Contained by
core: item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage orig
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain Empty element
Note

The example gives a quote of Toh 10 found in its Toh 3808 commentary. The <space> element is a stand in for an endnote in Toh 10. This allows the parser to highlight the full passage in the popup by ignoring the note.

Example
<qref="UT22084-029-001-354" type="substring"xml:id="UT23703-093-001-42816522"> <ptid="9245">because where there is no intrinsic nature there is no production, stopping,<space/> decrease, increase, defilement, or purification.</p> </q>
Content model 
<content>
<empty/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element space { empty }

1.64. <span>

<span> Used to indicate that a quoted passage to another published 84000 TEI text has a span in the middle of the quote that needs to be ignored by the parser.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Member of
macro.paraContent
Contained by
core: l p ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage orig
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front
May contain Character data only
Note

The example gives a quote of Toh 10 found in its Toh 3808 commentary. The <space> element is a stand in for an endnote in Toh 10. This allows the parser to highlight the full passage in the popup by ignoring the note.

Example
<qref="UT22084-029-001-1013" type="substring"xml:id="UT23703-093-001-42817036"> <ptid="10632">form is itself emptiness, emptiness is itself form.</p> <orig> <span>form</span> is itself emptiness, and emptiness is itself <span>form</span> </orig> </q>
Content model 
<content>
<textNode/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element span { text }

1.65. <sponsor>

<sponsor> States the sponsor of a the 84000 translation.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes
ref Matches the sponsor to the database
Status Optional
Contained by
header: titleStmt
May contain Character data only
Note

Denotes the sponsor of the 84000 translation; if there is one it should be listed in the <titleStmt> after any <author>s, <editor>s, or <consultant>s.

Example
<titleStmt> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pai ting nge dzin</title> <!--...list of other titles...--> <authorref="translators.xml#team-9" role="translatorMain">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author> <authorref="translators.xml#translator-46" role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa Tulku</author> <editorrole="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor> <consultantrole="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant> <sponsorref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
Content model 
<content>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element sponsor { attribute ref { text }?, text? }

1.66. <table>

<table> (table) contains text displayed in tabular form, in rows and columns. [14.1.1. TEI Tables]
Module figures
Attributes att.typed (@type)
tid Numbers the table in the text along with and in the same manner as paragraph, <p>; and line group, <l>, elements.
Status Optional
rend Modifies table's display in the HTML
Status Optional
Legal values are:
firstcol-30pc
Renders the first column with 30% width
firstcol-40pc
Renders the first column with 40% width
firstcol-50pc
Renders the first column with 50% width
Member of
endnote model.listLike section-content
Contained by
core: desc item l note p q ref title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage orig
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body div front trailer
May contain
core: graphic head lb media milestone note
figures: row
textstructure: trailer
Note

Tables contains an optional heading and a series of <row>s. Generally the style of the table will be generated automatically by the parser and the width of each column and row will be determined by the longest string of text in that column or row; however if the default table is rendered ineloquently in the HTML, as an option the rend attribute may be used to define the width of the first column: @rend="firstcol-30pc" will set the width of the first column to 30% of the width of the full table, "firstcol-40pc" and "firstcol-50pc" will set it to 40% and 50% respectively. This was used, for example, in the appendix of Toh 307 to display the tables there with a consistent column width in relation to each other.

Currently no type is being used, but this may be added to the schema and documentation when it becomes necessary. Cells and rows should be assigned role="label" if they are considered to be the label or heading in which the subsequent <cell>s are considered to be data relevant to that label. If a <row> contains the role="label" attribute, then all of its child <cell>s will be considered to be "label"s as well.

Note, when marking up <table>s the markup editor should check that the table renders properly in the reading room's web display. In addition, the table needs to be checked in the ebook display as well. This can be done by adding the code: ?viewmode=epub to the very end of the url address on the utilities page. In truth, the tables are not compatible with the ebook format, so the parser will instead display them as a bulleted list. The information in this list should be presented in a complete and eloquently readable way, otherwise the parser should be updated.

For further details on tables see Appendix B Topics: Tables.

Example Here is an example from Toh 361, notice that <note>s may be added at the foot of the <table> outside of any <row>s, but still wrapped within the <table>.
<tabletid="111"> <headtype="table">Deity Families</head> <rowrole="label"> <cell>Verses</cell> <cell>Aspect</cell> <cell>Vajrasattva</cell> <cell>Mahsattva</cell> <cell>Bodhisattva</cell> <cell>Samayasattva</cell> <cell>Vajrayoga</cell> <cell>Klacakra</cell> </row> <row> <cellrole="label">16163</cell> <cellrole="label">cakra</cell> <cell>secret</cell> <cell>navel</cell> <cell>heart</cell> <cell>throat</cell> <cell>forehead</cell> <cell>crown</cell> </row> <row> <cellrole="label">16469</cell> <cellrole="label">purifies*</cell> <cell>threefold existence</cell> <cell>passion</cell> <cell>hatred</cell> <cell>delusion</cell> <cell>anger</cell> <cell>attachment</cell> </row> <note>* Tentative interpretation.</note> </table>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content>
<sequencemaxOccurs="1"minOccurs="1">
<alternatemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="0">
<classRefkey="model.headLike"/>
<classRefkey="model.global"/>
</alternate>
<alternatemaxOccurs="1"minOccurs="1">
<sequencemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="1">
<elementRefkey="row"/>
<classRefkey="model.global"
maxOccurs="unbounded"minOccurs="0"/>
</sequence>
<sequencemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="1">
<classRefkey="model.graphicLike"/>
<classRefkey="model.global"
maxOccurs="unbounded"minOccurs="0"/>
</sequence>
</alternate>
<sequencemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="0">
<classRefkey="model.divBottom"/>
<classRefkey="model.global"
maxOccurs="unbounded"minOccurs="0"/>
</sequence>
</sequence>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element table
{
   att.typed.attributes,
   attribute tid { text }?,
   attribute rend { "firstcol-30pc" | "firstcol-40pc" | "firstcol-50pc" }?,
   (
      ( model.headLike | model.global )*,
      ( ( row, model.global* )+ | ( model.graphicLike, model.global* )+ ),
      ( model.divBottom, model.global* )*
   )
}

1.67. <taxonomy>

<taxonomy> (taxonomy) defines a typology either implicitly, by means of a bibliographic citation, or explicitly by a structured taxonomy. [2.3.7. The Classification Declaration]
Module header
Attributes att.global (@xml:lang, @xml:id) (att.global.rendition (@rend))
Contained by
header: classDecl
May contain
header: category
Note

Nested taxonomies are common in many fields, so the <taxonomy> element can be nested.

Example
<taxonomyxml:id="tax.b"> <bibl>Brown Corpus</bibl> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a"> <catDesc>Press Reportage</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a1"> <catDesc>Daily</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a2"> <catDesc>Sunday</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a3"> <catDesc>National</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a4"> <catDesc>Provincial</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a5"> <catDesc>Political</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.a6"> <catDesc>Sports</catDesc> </category> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.d"> <catDesc>Religion</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.d1"> <catDesc>Books</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tax.b.d2"> <catDesc>Periodicals and tracts</catDesc> </category> </category> </taxonomy>
Example
<taxonomy> <categoryxml:id="literature"> <catDesc>Literature</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="poetry"> <catDesc>Poetry</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="sonnet"> <catDesc>Sonnet</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="shakesSonnet"> <catDesc>Shakespearean Sonnet</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="petraSonnet"> <catDesc>Petrarchan Sonnet</catDesc> </category> </category> <categoryxml:id="haiku"> <catDesc>Haiku</catDesc> </category> </category> <categoryxml:id="drama"> <catDesc>Drama</catDesc> </category> </category> <categoryxml:id="meter"> <catDesc>Metrical Categories</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="feet"> <catDesc>Metrical Feet</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="iambic"> <catDesc>Iambic</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="trochaic"> <catDesc>trochaic</catDesc> </category> </category> <categoryxml:id="feetNumber"> <catDesc>Number of feet</catDesc> <categoryxml:id="pentameter"> <catDesc>>Pentameter</catDesc> </category> <categoryxml:id="tetrameter"> <catDesc>>Tetrameter</catDesc> </category> </category> </category> </taxonomy> <!-- elsewhere in document --> <lgana="#shakesSonnet #iambic #pentameter"> <l>Shall I compare thee to a summer's day</l> <!-- ... --> </lg>
Content model 
<content>
<elementRefkey="category"
maxOccurs="unbounded"minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element taxonomy { att.global.attributes, category* }

1.68. <teiHeader>

<teiHeader> (TEI header) supplies descriptive and declarative metadata associated with a digital resource or set of resources. [2.1.1. The TEI Header and Its Components 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module header
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
header: encodingDesc fileDesc profileDesc
Note

The following description from the University of Michigan is available as part of a PDF at http://www.lib.umich.edu/files/departments/dpp/20101113_06.pdf "The TEI header (<teiHeader>) is the virtual title page of a TEI document. It contains meta data (information about the TEI document). <teiHeader> is the first, mandatory child element of the root <TEI> element; therefore, it appears at the top (at the head) of every TEI document. The header meta data provides: 1. bibliographic record of the electronic text as well as the source from which the electronic text is derived 2. documentation of the encoding and editorial principles used in tagging the electronic text 3. terms for indexing, searching, and retrieval 4. a record of changes made to the electronic document. The header contains many specialised elements not found anywhere in the body of a TEI document (that is, everything after the close of <teiHeader>). These elements allow for highly structured descriptions of the document. Many parts of the header allow free-form prose descriptions as an alternative to the highly structured descriptions. Few header elements are required, so a header can be quite minimal."

Example
<teiHeader> <fileDesc> <titleStmt> <titletype="mainTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</title> <titletype="mainTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bhadraplarehiparipcch</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="longTitle" xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">phags pa tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen poi mdo</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahyna Stra The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</title> <titletype="longTitle" xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ryabhadraplarehiparipcchnmamahynastra</title> <authorrole="translatorMain">Translated by Karen Liljenberg and Ulrich Pagel<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</author> <authorrole="translatorEng">Karen Liljenberg</author> <authorrole="translatorEng">Ulrich Pagel</author> </titleStmt> <editionStmt> <edition>v 1.3 <date>2017</date> </edition> </editionStmt> <publicationStmtstatus="1"> <publisher> <name>84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</name> is a global non-profit initiative that aims to translate all of the Buddhas words into modern languages, and to make them available to everyone. </publisher> <availability> <licence> <graphicurl="http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by-nc-nd/2.0/88x31.png"/> <p>This work is provided under the protection of a Creative Commons CC BY-NC-ND (Attribution - Non-commercial - No-derivatives) 3.0 copyright. It may be copied or printed for fair use, but only with full attribution, and not for commercial advantage or personal compensation. For full details, see the Creative Commons license.</p> </licence> </availability> <idnoxml:id="UT22084-044-003"/> <note>An early mistake in the assigning of UT numbers within the 84000 project means that these ids diverge slightly from the standard logic.</note> <date>2017-02-25</date> </publicationStmt> <sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh83"type="text"> <ref>Toh 83</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha), folios 71.a94.b</biblScope> <!--series>Deg Kangyur</series>, <biblScope>vol. 44 (dkon brtsegs, cha)</biblScope>, <citedRange>folios 71a94a</citedRange--> <authorrole="translatorTib">Jinamitra</author> <authorrole="translatorTib">Surendrabodhi</author> <authorrole="translatorTib">Yesh D</author> <locationcount-pages="48" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="188"number="44" start-page="141"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC14667"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC11626" work="W22084"/> </bibl> </sourceDesc> <notesStmt> <notedate-time="2019-02-26T08:34:43.421Z" type="lastUpdated"user="celso">26/02/2019 08:34:43</note> </notesStmt> </fileDesc> </teiHeader>
Content model 
<content>
<elementRefkey="fileDesc"/>
<alternatemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="0">
<elementRefkey="encodingDesc"/>
<elementRefkey="profileDesc"/>
</alternate>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element teiHeader { fileDesc, ( encodingDesc | profileDesc )* }

1.69. <term>

<term> (term) contains a single-word, multi-word, or symbolic designation which is regarded as a technical term. [3.4.1. Terms and Glosses]
Module core
Attributes att.global (xml:id, @xml:lang) att.global.rendition (@rend)
type Identifies the term in terms of its relation to the glossary, or its function within the glossary. See more detail on how to apply this type attribute in Appendix: Applying Type Attributes for the Sanskrit Term.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
ignore
definition
alternative
semanticReconstruction
transliterationReconstruction
sourceAttested
person-interlocutor
person-main-speaker
person-topical
main-subject
secondary-subject
ref (reference) For the <term> element, the @ref attribute should be used when there are three or more glossary entries with the exact same string and the instances of the term within the body of the text need to be distinguished. In such cases, the <gloss> entry should be mode="marked".
Derived from att.canonical
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.pointer separated by whitespace
status Identifies whether the term has been verified in the source or according to an authoritative dictionary. Tibetan may be verified by markup using the python script for checking the TEI against the eKangyur OR by checking it against the eKangyur in the glossary editing tool. Sanskrit may be verified either during markup or post-markup by a Sanskrit specialist in editorial.
Status Optional
Legal values are:
verified
Member of
model.emphLike
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor emph expan foreign gloss item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage orig
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr date distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi lb media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
header: idno
tagdocs: code
character data
Note

In 84000 texts the <term> element is used for glossary entries or to denote the way a string within the text is to linked to the glossary by the parser. See the following examples:

Example Primarily the <term> element is used to list glossary terms in the back matter of a text. For each individual <gloss> element, which constitutes a single glossary entry, a list of several <term> elements are used (see the example below). The first <term> element, which should have no attritutes, shows the English translation of the term or the string used in for that term as it is found in the text. This first <term> element indicates to the parser which word or string of text to link to the glossary entry, and it will create a link for every instance of that term that is found in the text. The next <term> elements that follow within the <gloss> list the Wylie, Tibetan, and Sanskrit for that term, all indicated by the xml:lang attribute with the appropriate value. After that a definition is given in its own <term> element with the type="definition" attribute. Finally, if there are any alternate translations used for the term within the text that should be linked to this gloss, they are listed last each marked by type="alternative". These instances of alternative strings of text will also be linked to the glossary entry wherever they are found in the text. All of this can be seen in the first example below. For further notes about the glossary see Appendix: Guidelines for Glossary.
<glosstype="term" xml:id="UT22084-046-001-2968"> <term>hearer</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> nyan thos </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">rvaka</term> <termtype="definition">A follower of the early teachings of the Buddha, focusing on the monastic lifestyle. Also translated as "<termtype="ignore">listener</term>."</term> <termtype="alternative">Listener</term> </gloss>
Example The <term> element may also be used in the text itself to alter the way a string of text is to be linked to the glossary. For example, a string of text can bypass being linked if it is placed within a <term type="ignore"> as like the following example. Alternatively, if the parent <gloss> element for an entry is given the attribute mode="marked" then it will only link to instances in the text that are contained within a <term> element. If there are three or more glossary entries of the same string, then these may be more precisely distinguished within the body of text by adding a @ref attribute pointing to the specific glossary entry to which they refer (In this situations the <gloss> entry should be mode="marked"). For more details on how the glossary functions on the web page see Appendix: Guidelines for Glossary.
<!--A Term is bypassed from being linked within the text with the <term type="ignore"> element.--> Indeed he is a Dharma king who <termtype="ignore">guides</term> according to the Dharma. <!-- Alternatively, the gloss is given the atribute mode="marked" --> <item> <glossmode="marked"priority="0" type="term"xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185"> <term>appropriate</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">dna</term> <termtype="definition">See appropriation.</term> <termtype="alternative">appropriated</term> </gloss> </item> <!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <ptid="38"> Bhadrapla said, Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying persons limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying persons sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body? </p>
Content model 
<content>
<macroRefkey="macro.phraseSeq"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element term
{
   att.global.attribute.xmllang,
   att.global.rendition.attribute.rend,
   attribute type
   {
      "ignore"
    |"definition"
    |"alternative"
    |"semanticReconstruction"
    |"transliterationReconstruction"
    |"sourceAttested"
    |"person-interlocutor"
    |"person-main-speaker"
    |"person-topical"
    |"main-subject"
    |"secondary-subject"
   }?,
   attribute ref { list { + } }?,
   attribute status { "verified" }?,
   macro.phraseSeq
}

1.70. <text>

<text> (text) contains a single text of any kind, whether unitary or composite, for example a poem or drama, a collection of essays, a novel, a dictionary, or a corpus sample. [4. Default Text Structure 15.1. Varieties of Composite Text]
Module textstructure
Contained by
textstructure: TEI
May contain
textstructure: back body front
Note

In the case of the 84000 translations, the <text> element is opened right below the <teiHeader> element. It includes within it the translated work, as well as the front and back matter.

Example
<text> <front> <divtype="summary"/> <!--... etc.--> </front> <body/> <back/> </text>
Content model 
<content>
<elementRefkey="front"/>
<elementRefkey="body"minOccurs="0"/>
<elementRefkey="back"minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element text { front, body?, back? }

1.71. <textClass>

<textClass> (text classification) groups information which describes the nature or topic of a text in terms of a standard classification scheme, thesaurus, etc. [2.4.3. The Text Classification]
Module header
Contained by
header: profileDesc
May contain
header: catRef keywords
Example
<taxonomy> <categoryxml:id="acprose"> <catDesc>Academic prose</catDesc> </category> <!-- other categories here --> </taxonomy> <!-- ... --> <textClass> <catReftarget="#acprose"/> <classCodescheme="http://www.udcc.org">001.9</classCode> <keywordsscheme="http://authorities.loc.gov"> <list> <item>End of the world</item> <item>History - philosophy</item> </list> </keywords> </textClass>
Content model 
<content>
<elementRefkey="keywords"minOccurs="0"/>
<elementRefkey="catRef"minOccurs="0"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element textClass { keywords?, catRef? }

1.72. <title>

<title> (title) contains a title for any kind of work. [3.12.2.2. Titles, Authors, and Editors 2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2.5. The Series Statement]
Module core
Attributes
xml:lang
Derived from att.global
Status Required
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Ko-Ltn
Korean written in Roman script
Ar-Ltn
Arabic written in Roman script
Fa-Ltn
Persian written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
la
Latin
nl
Dutch; Flemish
ru
Russian
da
Danish
pt
Portuguese
es
Spanish
sv
Swedish
no
Norwegian
po
Polish
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
saka-Ltn
Saka written in Roman script.
sogdian-Ltn
Sogdian written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
rend (rendition) @rend is used in our TEI specifically for the value "reconstruction," when a Sa-Ltn title is reconstructed from the Tibetan.
Derived from att.global.rendition
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.word separated by whitespace
Legal values are:
reconstruction
A Sanskrit, "Sa-Ltn" title which is reconstructed from Tibetan.
type classifies the title according to the TBRC typology. classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.
Derived from att.typed
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
Legal values are:
mainTitle
longTitle
otherTitle
shortcode
Note

This attribute is provided for convenience in analysing titles and processing them according to their type; where such specialized processing is not necessary, there is no need for such analysis, and the entire title, including subtitles and any parallel titles, may be enclosed within a single <title> element.

group Allows the grouping multiple titles together as equivalents in different languages, e.g. short title, long title, etc...
Status Optional
Member of
bibl-section-content head-content model.emphLike paragraph translation-chapter
Contained by
core: author bibl biblScope desc distinct editor expan foreign head item l label note p publisher q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage orig
figures: cell
header: publicationStmt titleStmt
textstructure: back body front trailer
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
derived-module-NewODD: canonDef mantra modPassage space span
figures: table
header: idno
tagdocs: code
character data
Note

The title tag can be used throughout the TEI document. In the case of the header, it appears with type attributes with values of "mainTitle" or "longTitle" and the language attributes "bo", "eng", "Sa-Ltn", "Bo-Ltn", or "zh" depending on if it is in Tibetan, English, Sanskrit, Wylie, or Chinese. In the case of the header appearance, title denotes the title of the translated work.

Example Below is an example from the <titleStmt> in the teiHeader in Toh 127:
<titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">ting nge dzin gyi rgyal poi mdo</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="en">The King of Samdhis Stra</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Samdhirjastra</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">phags pa chos thams cad kyi rang bzhin mnyam pa nyid rnam par spros pa ting nge dzin gyi rgyal po zhes bya ba theg pa chen poi mdo</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="en">The Mahyna Stra The King of Samdhis, the Revealed Equality of the Nature of All Phenomena</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ryasarvadharmasvabhvasamatvipacitasamdhirjanmamahynastra</title> <titletype="otherTitle"xml:lang="zh"></title>
Example When the title tag is used in the front or body or back matter, it can denote the title of any published work, and will be displayed italicized in the web display. All <title> should have a xml:lan attribute with the value appropriate to the language used. Below is an example from Toh 544, from the introduction.
... lesser-known forms of Majur, Siddhaikavra is also the subject of four sdhanas in the <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Sdhanaml</title> (Bhattacharyya 1968) where some of his descriptions correspond in detail to the...
Example It should also be used for bibliography entries, for example from Toh 127:
<biblxml:id="UT22084-055-001-4768">Candrakrti. <titlexml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dbu ma la jug pa</title> (<titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Madhyamakvatra</title>) [<titlexml:lang="en">Entering the Middle Way</title>]. Toh 3861, Deg Tengyur vol. 204 (dbu ma a), folios 201.b219.a.</bibl>
Content model 
<content>
<macroRefkey="macro.paraContent"/>
</content>
Schema Declaration 
element title
{
   attribute xml:lang
   {
      "Bo-Ltn"
    |"Gu-Ltn"
    |"Hi-Ltn"
    |"Ja-Ltn"
    |"Kn-Ltn"
    |"Mr-Ltn"
    |"Mn-Ltn"
    |"Pi-Ltn"
    |"Pra-Ltn"
    |"Sa-Ltn"
    |"Ta-Ltn"
    |"Th-Ltn"
    |"Zh-Ltn"
    |"Mn-Ltn"
    |"Ko-Ltn"
    |"Ar-Ltn"
    |"Fa-Ltn"
    |"bo"
    |"cs"
    |"de"
    |"el"
    |"en"
    |"fr"
    |"it"
    |"ja"
    |"la"
    |"nl"
    |"ru"
    |"da"
    |"pt"
    |"es"
    |"sv"
    |"no"
    |"po"
    |"zh"
    |"middle_indic-Ltn"
    |"saka-Ltn"
    |"sogdian-Ltn"
    |"mixed"
   },
   attribute rend { list { "reconstruction"+ } }?,
   attribute type { "mainTitle" | "longTitle" | "otherTitle" | "shortcode" }?,
   attribute group { text }?,
   macro.paraContent
}

1.73. <titleStmt>

<titleStmt> (title statement) groups information about the title of a work and those responsible for its content. [2.2.1. The Title Statement 2.2. The File Description]
Module header
Contained by
header: fileDesc
May contain
core: editor lb title
derived-module-NewODD: consultant sponsor
character data
Note

Appears once in the <teiHeader>. It should contain the nine title variations for each text. This should include four "mainTitle"s and four "longTitle"s (for Wylie, Tibetan, English, and Sanskrit); and one "otherTitle" (for Chinese). If any of these nine default titles are not present, they should contain an empty element as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. It may contain additional title(s) from other sources, but these should be marked as type="otherTitle". Following the titles, there needs to be <author> elements given for each person or group involved in the translation of the text (these authors are the translators of the English, not the original translators of the Tibetan who will be listed later on in the <sourceDesc>). After the <author>s, any <editor>s, <consultant>s, or <sponsor>s may be listed in that order. For these latter three, DO NOT leave empty elements as placeholders if they are not present.

Example
<titleStmt> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">bsod nams thams cad bsdus pai ting nge dzin</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="en">The Absorption That Encapsulates All Merit</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Sarvapuyasamuccayasamdhi</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">phags pa bsod nams thams cad bsdus pai ting nge dzin ces bya ba theg pa chen poi mdo</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahyna Stra The Absorption That Encapsulates All Merit</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ryasarvapuyasamuccayasamdhinmamahynastra</title> <titletype="otherTitle"xml:lang="zh"></title> <authorref="translators.xml#team-9" role="translatorMain">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author> <authorref="translators.xml#translator-40" role="translatorEng"/> <authorref="translators.xml#translator-78" role="translatorEng"/> <authorref="translators.xml#translator-50" role="translatorEng"/> <authorref="translators.xml#translator-46" role="translatorEng">Khenpo Trokpa Tulku</author> <editorrole="projectEditor">Andreas Doctor</editor> <consultantrole="advisor">Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche</consultant> <sponsorref="sponsors.xml#sponsor-999">anonymous</sponsor> </titleStmt>
(See how this example is displayed in reading room.)
Content model 
<content>translatorMaintranslatorEngpreface</content>
Schema Declaration 
element titleStmt
{
   title*,
   (
      element author
      {
         attribute role { "translatorMain" },
         attribute ref { text }?,
         ( text | lb )*
      }?
    |element author
      {
         attribute role { "translatorEng" | "preface" },
         attribute ref { text }?,
         text*
      }*
    |editor*
    |consultant*
    |sponsor*
   )*
}

1.74. <trailer>

<trailer> contains a closing title or footer appearing at the end of a division of a text. [4.2.4. Content of Textual Divisions 4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module textstructure
Attributes att.placement (@place)
tid Numbers paragraph and line groups in a particular text. It is also applicable to trailers which replace the <p> element.
Status Required
Member of
model.divBottomPart section-content
Contained by
figures: table
textstructure: back body div front
May contain
core: abbr bibl date desc distinct emph expan foreign gloss graphic hi l label lb lg list media milestone name note ptr q ref term title
figures: table
header: idno
tagdocs: code
character data
Note

The trailer should be used for the last sentence of a chapter or text that declares it is the end of that chapter or text. This doesn't include colophons. This element functions like the paragraph, <p>, element and may require a milestone preceding it, and the tid attribute. In the final web display the trailer will be italicized. All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any <title>s that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks to indicate that it is a title.

Example
<milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-080-015-44"/> <trailertid="1938">This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caamahroaa tantra called <titlexml:lang="en">The Sole Hero</title>.</trailer>
Example Like the <p> element, the <trailer> may contain <note>s or <ref>s, as like the following example.
<milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-055-001-512"/> <trailertid="3265">Conclusion of the third chapter, Praise of the Buddhas Qualities. <noteindex="248"place="end" xml:id="UT22084-055-001-513"> According to the commentary, the title of this chapter is Mindfulness of the Buddhas Qualities.</note> <refcRef="B2"type="bampo"/> </trailer>
(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room.)
Content model 
<content/>
Schema Declaration 
element trailer
{
   att.placement.attributes,
   attribute tid { text },
   (
      text
    |lg
    |ref-canonical
    |ref-other
    |model.gLike
    |model.phrase
    |model.inter
    |model.lLike
    |model.global
   )*
}

1.75. <volume>

<volume> Used in the location to define the volume(s) in which the text is located.
Module derived-module-NewODD
Attributes
number
Status Required
start-page
Status Required
end-page
Status Required
Contained by
derived-module-NewODD: location
May contain Empty element
Note

Identifies the volume of the text. This element is key for determining the alignment of the folio references linked to the eKangyur.

Example
<sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh11"type="text"> <!--...--> <locationcount-pages="788" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="593"number="31" start-page="414"/> <volumeend-page="611"number="32" start-page="2"/> </location> <!--...--> </bibl> </sourceDesc>

2. Model classes

2.1. model.attributable

model.attributablegroups elements that contain a word or phrase that can be attributed to a source. [3.3.3. Quotation 4.3.2. Floating Texts]
Module tei
Used by
macro.phraseSeq model.inter
Members model.quoteLike

2.2. model.biblLike

model.biblLikegroups elements containing a bibliographic description. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by
model.inter
Members bibl

2.3. model.biblPart

model.biblPartgroups elements which represent components of a bibliographic description. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]
Module tei
Used by
bibl
Members model.imprintPart [biblScope publisher] model.respLike [author editor] bibl edition

2.4. model.common

model.commongroups common chunk- and inter-level elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
div
Members model.divPart [model.lLike [l] model.pLike [p] lg] model.inter [model.attributable [model.quoteLike] model.biblLike [bibl] model.egLike model.labelLike [desc label] model.listLike [list table] model.oddDecl model.stageLike] q
Note

This class defines the set of chunk- and inter-level elements; it is used in many content models, including those for textual divisions.

2.5. model.dateLike

model.dateLikegroups elements containing temporal expressions. [3.6.4. Dates and Times 13.4. Dates]
Module tei
Used by
model.pPart.data
Members date

2.6. model.descLike

model.descLikegroups elements which contain a description of their function.
Module tei
Used by
media
Members desc

2.7. model.divBottom

model.divBottomgroups elements appearing at the end of a text division. [4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module tei
Used by
div table
Members model.divBottomPart [trailer] model.divWrapper

2.8. model.divBottomPart

model.divBottomPartgroups elements which can occur only at the end of a text division. [4.6. Title Pages]
Module tei
Used by
model.divBottom
Members trailer

2.9. model.divLike

model.divLikegroups elements used to represent un-numbered generic structural divisions.
Module tei
Used by
div
Members div

2.10. model.divPart

model.divPartgroups paragraph-level elements appearing directly within divisions. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
macro.specialPara model.common
Members model.lLike [l] model.pLike [p] lg
Note

Note that this element class does not include members of the model.inter class, which can appear either within or between paragraph-level items.

2.11. model.divTop

model.divTopgroups elements appearing at the beginning of a text division. [4.2. Elements Common to All Divisions]
Module tei
Used by
div
Members model.divTopPart [model.headLike [head]] model.divWrapper

2.12. model.divTopPart

model.divTopPartgroups elements which can occur only at the beginning of a text division. [4.6. Title Pages]
Module tei
Used by
model.divTop
Members model.headLike [head]

2.13. model.emphLike

model.emphLikegroups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct and to which a specific function can be attributed. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
model.highlighted model.limitedPhrase
Members code distinct emph foreign gloss term title

2.14. model.encodingDescPart

model.encodingDescPartgroups elements which may be used inside <encodingDesc> and appear multiple times.
Module tei
Used by
encodingDesc
Members classDecl

2.15. model.global

model.globalgroups elements which may appear at any point within a TEI text. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
bibl div endnote macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara model.paraPart table trailer
Members model.global.edit model.global.meta model.milestoneLike [lb milestone] model.noteLike [note]

2.16. model.graphicLike

model.graphicLikegroups elements containing images, formulae, and similar objects. [3.10. Graphics and Other Non-textual Components]
Module tei
Used by
model.phrase table
Members graphic media

2.17. model.headLike

model.headLikegroups elements used to provide a title or heading at the start of a text division.
Module tei
Used by
model.divTopPart table
Members head

2.18. model.hiLike

model.hiLikegroups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct but to which no specific function can be attributed. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
model.highlighted model.limitedPhrase
Members hi q

2.19. model.highlighted

model.highlightedgroups phrase-level elements which are typographically distinct. [3.3. Highlighting and Quotation]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.phrase
Members model.emphLike [code distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q]

2.20. model.imprintPart

model.imprintPartgroups the bibliographic elements which occur inside imprints. [3.12. Bibliographic Citations and References]

Members biblScope publisher

2.21. model.inter

model.intergroups elements which can appear either within or between paragraph-like elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]

Used by
macro.limitedContent macro.paraContent macro.specialPara model.common model.paraPart trailer
Members model.attributable [model.quoteLike] model.biblLike [bibl] model.egLike model.labelLike [desc label] model.listLike [list table] model.oddDecl model.stageLike

2.22. model.lLike

model.lLikegroups elements representing metrical components such as verse lines.

Members l

2.23. model.labelLike

model.labelLikegroups elements used to gloss or explain other parts of a document.
Module tei
Used by
model.inter
Members desc label

2.24. model.limitedPhrase

model.limitedPhrasegroups phrase-level elements excluding those elements primarily intended for transcription of existing sources. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
macro.limitedContent
Members model.emphLike [code distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q] model.pPart.data [model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]] model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.msdesc model.phrase.xml model.ptrLike [ptr ref]

2.26. model.milestoneLike

Members lb milestone

2.27. model.nameLike

model.nameLikegroups elements which name or refer to a person, place, or organization.
Module tei
Used by
model.pPart.data
Members model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno
Note

A superset of the naming elements that may appear in datelines, addresses, statements of responsibility, etc.

2.28. model.nameLike.agent

model.nameLike.agentgroups elements which contain names of individuals or corporate bodies. [3.6. Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses]
Module tei
Used by
model.nameLike
Members name
Note

This class is used in the content model of elements which reference names of people or organizations.

2.29. model.noteLike

model.noteLikegroups globally-available note-like elements. [3.9. Notes, Annotation, and Indexing]

2.31. model.pPart.data

model.pPart.datagroups phrase-level elements containing names, dates, numbers, measures, and similar data. [3.6. Names, Numbers, Dates, Abbreviations, and Addresses]
Module tei
Used by
bibl model.limitedPhrase model.phrase
Members model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]

2.32. model.pPart.edit

Members model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.transcriptional

2.33. model.pPart.editorial

Module tei
Used by

Members abbr expan

2.34. model.paraPart

model.paraPartgroups elements that may appear in paragraphs and similar elements [3.1. Paragraphs]
Module tei
Used by
Members model.gLike model.global [model.global.edit model.global.meta model.milestoneLike [lb milestone] model.noteLike [note]] model.inter [model.attributable [model.quoteLike] model.biblLike [bibl] model.egLike model.labelLike [desc label] model.listLike [list table] model.oddDecl model.stageLike] model.lLike [l] model.phrase [model.graphicLike [graphic media] model.highlighted [model.emphLike [code distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q]] model.lPart model.pPart.data [model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]] model.pPart.edit [model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.transcriptional] model.pPart.msdesc model.phrase.xml model.ptrLike [ptr ref] model.segLike model.specDescLike] lg

2.35. model.phrase

model.phrasegroups elements which can occur at the level of individual words or phrases. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
endnote macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara model.paraPart trailer
Members model.graphicLike [graphic media] model.highlighted [model.emphLike [code distinct emph foreign gloss term title] model.hiLike [hi q]] model.lPart model.pPart.data [model.addressLike model.dateLike [date] model.measureLike model.nameLike [model.nameLike.agent [name] model.offsetLike model.placeStateLike [model.placeNamePart] idno]] model.pPart.edit [model.pPart.editorial [abbr expan] model.pPart.transcriptional] model.pPart.msdesc model.phrase.xml model.ptrLike [ptr ref] model.segLike model.specDescLike
Note

This class of elements can occur within paragraphs, list items, lines of verse, etc.

2.38. model.respLike

model.respLikegroups elements which are used to indicate intellectual or other significant responsibility, for example within a bibliographic element.

model.biblPart
Members author editor

3. Attribute classes

3.1. att.cReferencing

att.cReferencingprovides attributes that may be used to supply a canonical reference as a means of identifying the target of a pointer.
Module tei
Members ref
Attributes
cRef (canonical reference) specifies the destination of the pointer by supplying a canonical reference expressed using the scheme defined in a <refsDecl> element in the TEI header
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
Note

The value of cRef should be constructed so that when the algorithm for the resolution of canonical references (described in section 16.2.5. Canonical References) is applied to it the result is a valid URI reference to the intended target.

The <refsDecl> to use may be indicated with the decls attribute.

Currently these Guidelines only provide for a single canonical reference to be encoded on any given <ptr> element.

3.2. att.canonical

att.canonicalprovides attributes that can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced. [13.1.1. Linking Names and Their Referents]
Module tei
Members att.naming[author editor] catDesc date publisher term
Attributes
key provides an externally-defined means of identifying the entity (or entities) being named, using a coded value of some kind.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.text
<author> <namekey="name 427308" type="organisation">[New Zealand Parliament, Legislative Council]</name> </author>
<author> <namekey="Hugo, Victor (1802-1885)" ref="http://www.idref.fr/026927608">Victor Hugo</name> </author>
Note

The value may be a unique identifier from a database, or any other externally-defined string identifying the referent.

No particular syntax is proposed for the values of the key attribute, since its form will depend entirely on practice within a given project. For the same reason, this attribute is not recommended in data interchange, since there is no way of ensuring that the values used by one project are distinct from those used by another. In such a situation, a preferable approach for magic tokens which follows standard practice on the Web is to use a ref attribute whose value is a tag URI as defined in RFC 4151.

ref (reference) provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.pointer separated by whitespace
<nameref="http://viaf.org/viaf/109557338" type="person">Seamus Heaney</name>
Note

The value must point directly to one or more XML elements or other resources by means of one or more URIs, separated by whitespace. If more than one is supplied the implication is that the name identifies several distinct entities.

3.3. att.global

att.globalprovides attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1. Global Attributes]
Module tei
Members author bibl canonDef catDesc catRef category classDecl code desc div editor encodingDesc foreign gloss hi idno item keywords mantra media milestone modPassage note ref taxonomy term title
Attributes att.global.rendition (@rend)
xml:lang
Status Optional
Legal values are:
Bo-Ltn
Tibetan written in Roman script (Wylie or otherwise)
Gu-Ltn
Gujarti written in Roman script
Hi-Ltn
Hindi written in Roman script
Ja-Ltn
Japanese written in Roman script
Kn-Ltn
Kannada written in Roman script
Mr-Ltn
Marathi written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Pi-Ltn
Pali written in Roman script
Pra-Ltn
Prakrit written in Roman script
Sa-Ltn
Sanskrit written in Roman script (Note: the term will be italicized. do not tag this for terms that are left unitalicized in 84000 texts like sutra, nagas, dharma, Sanskrit names, etc.)
Ta-Ltn
Tamil written in Roman script
Th-Ltn
Thai written in Roman script
Zh-Ltn
Chinese written in Roman script
Mn-Ltn
Mongolian written in Roman script
Ko-Ltn
Korean written in Roman script
Ar-Ltn
Arabic written in Roman script
Fa-Ltn
Persian written in Roman script
bo
Tibetan in Tibetan script (Use Bo-Ltn if in Roman script or Wylie)
cs
Czech
de
German (Deutsch)
el
Greek
en
English
fr
French
it
Italian
ja
Japanese in Japanese script (Use Ja-Ltn if in Roman script)
la
Latin
nl
Dutch; Flemish
ru
Russian
da
Danish
pt
Portuguese
es
Spanish
sv
Swedish
no
Norwegian
po
Polish
zh
Chinese in Chinese script (Use Zh-Ltn if in Roman script)
middle_indic-Ltn
Middle Indic written in Roman script.
saka-Ltn
Saka written in Roman script.
sogdian-Ltn
Sogdian written in Roman script.
mixed
This element contains strings mixed with different languages. They will be differentiated within this element by <foreign> tags, or left unwrapped if they are the default English.
xml:id (identifier) provides a unique identifier for the element bearing the attribute.
Status Optional
Datatype ID
Note

The xml:id attribute may be used to specify a canonical reference for an element; see section 3.11. Reference Systems.

3.4. att.global.rendition

att.global.renditionprovides rendering attributes common to all elements in the TEI encoding scheme. [1.3.1.1.3. Rendition Indicators]
Module tei
Members att.global [author bibl canonDef catDesc catRef category classDecl code desc div editor encodingDesc foreign gloss hi idno item keywords mantra media milestone modPassage note ref taxonomy term title]
Attributes
rend (rendition) indicates how the element in question was rendered or presented in the source text.
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.word separated by whitespace
<headrend="align(center) case(allcaps)"> <lb/>To The <lb/>Duchesse <lb/>of <lb/>Newcastle, <lb/>On Her <lb/> <hirend="case(mixed)">New Blazing-World</hi>. </head>
Note

These Guidelines make no binding recommendations for the values of the rend attribute; the characteristics of visual presentation vary too much from text to text and the decision to record or ignore individual characteristics varies too much from project to project. Some potentially useful conventions are noted from time to time at appropriate points in the Guidelines. The values of the rend attribute are a set of sequence-indeterminate individual tokens separated by whitespace.

3.5. att.internetMedia

att.internetMediaprovides attributes for specifying the type of a computer resource using a standard taxonomy.
Module tei
Members att.media [graphic media] ptr ref
Attributes
mimeType (MIME media type) specifies the applicable multimedia internet mail extension (MIME) media type
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.word separated by whitespace
Example In this example mimeType is used to indicate that the URL points to a TEI XML file encoded in UTF-8.
<refmimeType="application/tei+xml; charset=UTF-8" target="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TEIC/TEI/dev/P5/Source/guidelines-en.xml"/>
Note

This attribute class provides an attribute for describing a computer resource, typically available over the internet, using a value taken from a standard taxonomy. At present only a single taxonomy is supported, the Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) Media Type system. This typology of media types is defined by the Internet Engineering Task Force in RFC 2046. The list of types is maintained by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). The mimeType attribute must have a value taken from this list.

3.6. att.media

att.mediaprovides attributes for specifying display and related properties of external media.
Module tei
Members graphic media
Attributes att.internetMedia (@mimeType)

3.7. att.placement

att.placementprovides attributes for describing where on the source page or object a textual element appears. [3.5.3. Additions, Deletions, and Omissions 11.3.1.4. Additions and Deletions]
Module tei
Members note trailer
Attributes
place specifies where this item is placed.
Status Recommended
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.enumerated separated by whitespace
Suggested values include:
top
at the top of the page
bottom
at the foot of the page
margin
in the margin (left, right, or both)
opposite
on the opposite, i.e. facing, page
overleaf
on the other side of the leaf
above
above the line
right
to the right, e.g. to the right of a vertical line of text, or to the right of a figure
below
below the line
left
to the left, e.g. to the left of a vertical line of text, or to the left of a figure
end
at the end of e.g. chapter or volume.
inline
within the body of the text.
inspace
in a predefined space, for example left by an earlier scribe.
<addplace="margin">[An addition written in the margin]</add> <addplace="bottom opposite">[An addition written at the foot of the current page and also on the facing page]</add>
<noteplace="bottom">Ibid, p.7</note>

3.8. att.pointing

att.pointingprovides a set of attributes used by all elements which point to other elements by means of one or more URI references. [1.3.1.1.2. Language Indicators 3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References]
Module tei
Members catRef ptr ref
Attributes
target specifies the destination of the reference by supplying one or more URI References
Status Optional
Datatype 1 occurrences ofteidata.pointer separated by whitespace
Note

One or more syntactically valid URI references, separated by whitespace. Because whitespace is used to separate URIs, no whitespace is permitted inside a single URI. If a whitespace character is required in a URI, it should be escaped with the normal mechanism, e.g. TEI%20Consortium.

Schematron
<sch:rulecontext="tei:*[not(self::tei:schemaSpec)][@targetLang]"> <sch:asserttest="@target">@targetLang should only be used on <sch:name/> if @target is specified.</sch:assert> </sch:rule>

3.9. att.resourced

att.resourcedprovides attributes by which a resource (such as an externally held media file) may be located.
Module tei
Members graphic media
Attributes
url (uniform resource locator) specifies the URL from which the media concerned may be obtained.
Status Required
Datatype teidata.pointer

3.10. att.timed

att.timedprovides attributes common to those elements which have a duration in time, expressed either absolutely or by reference to an alignment map. [8.3.5. Temporal Information]
Module tei
Members media
Attributes
start indicates the location within a temporal alignment at which this element begins.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.pointer
Note

If no value is supplied, the element is assumed to follow the immediately preceding element at the same hierarchic level.

end indicates the location within a temporal alignment at which this element ends.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.pointer
Note

If no value is supplied, the element is assumed to precede the immediately following element at the same hierarchic level.

3.11. att.translatable

att.translatableprovides attributes used to indicate the status of a translatable portion of an ODD document.
Module tagdocs
Members desc
Attributes
versionDate specifies the date on which the source text was extracted and sent to the translator
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.temporal.working
Note

The versionDate attribute can be used to determine whether a translation might need to be revisited, by comparing the modification date on the containing file with the versionDate value on the translation. If the file has changed, changelogs can be checked to see whether the source text has been modified since the translation was made.

3.12. att.typed

att.typedprovides attributes that can be used to classify or subclassify elements in any way. [1.3.1. Attribute Classes 17.1.1. Words and Above 3.6.1. Referring Strings 3.7. Simple Links and Cross-References 3.6.5. Abbreviations and Their Expansions 3.13.1. Core Tags for Verse 7.2.5. Speech Contents 4.1.1. Un-numbered Divisions 4.1.2. Numbered Divisions 4.2.1. Headings and Trailers 4.4. Virtual Divisions 13.3.2.3. Personal Relationships 11.3.1.1. Core Elements for Transcriptional Work 16.1.1. Pointers and Links 16.3. Blocks, Segments, and Anchors 12.2. Linking the Apparatus to the Text 22.5.1.2. Defining Content Models: RELAX NG 8.3. Elements Unique to Spoken Texts 23.3.1.3. Modification of Attribute and Attribute Value Lists]
Module tei
Members bibl desc distinct div gloss graphic head idno lg list media note ref table term title
Attributes
type characterizes the element in some sense, using any convenient classification scheme or typology.
Status Optional
Datatype teidata.enumerated
<divtype="verse"> <head>Night in Tarras</head> <lgtype="stanza"> <l>At evening tramping on the hot white road</l> <l></l> </lg> <lgtype="stanza"> <l>A wind sprang up from nowhere as the sky</l> <l></l> </lg> </div>
Note

The type attribute is present on a number of elements, not all of which are members of att.typed, usually because these elements restrict the possible values for the attribute in a specific way.

Schematron
<sch:rulecontext="tei:*[@subtype]"> <sch:asserttest="@type">The <sch:name/> element should not be categorized in detail with @subtype unless also categorized in general with @type</sch:assert> </sch:rule>
Note

When appropriate, values from an established typology should be used. Alternatively a typology may be defined in the associated TEI header. If values are to be taken from a project-specific list, this should be defined using the <valList> element in the project-specific schema description, as described in 23.3.1.3. Modification of Attribute and Attribute Value Lists .

4. Macros

4.1. anyAttribute

anyAttribute
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
anyContent cache
Declaration 
anyAttribute = attribute * - xml:id { text }*

4.2. anyContent

anyContent
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
anyContent cache
Declaration 
anyContent = element * - idno { anyAttribute, anyContent }*

4.3. bibl-section-content

bibl-section-content
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back
Declaration 
bibl-section-content =
   (
      element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }
    |p
    |milestone
    |hi
    |lb
    |element bibl
      {
         attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
         (
            title
          |foreign
          |distinct
          |emph
          |lb
          |ptr
          |ref-other
          |hi
          |note
          |element author { string }
          |element date { string }
          |text
         )+
      }
   )*

4.4. cache

cache
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
TEI
Declaration 
cache =
   element d17307333e5a1309:notes-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 &element d17307333e9a1309:milestones-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 &element d17307333e13a1309:folios-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?
 &element d17307333e17a1309:glossary-cache { anyAttribute, anyContent }?

4.5. endnote

endnote
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
head-content l paragraph translation-chapter
Declaration 
endnote =
   element note
   {
      attribute index { xsd:integer }?,
      attribute place { "end" },
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      (
         text
       |model.gLike
       |model.phrase
       |table
       |list
       |element lg
         {
            attribute type { "sdom" | "bar_sdom" | "spyi_sdom" }?,
            ( l | mantra | modPassage | canonRef )+,
            ( , , ,  )+
         }
       |element p { attribute key { text }?, macro.paraContent }
       |model.global
       |mantra
       |modPassage
       |space
       |canonDef
       |ref-other
      )*
   }

4.6. head-content

head-content
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back bibl-section-content body front translation-chapter translation-section-head-content
Declaration 
head-content =
   attribute tid { text }?,
   (
      string { minLength = "1" }
    |( ( endnote | title | foreign | distinct )+ & text )
   )

4.7. list-in-front-body

list-in-front-body
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
section-content
Declaration 
list-in-front-body =
   element list
   {
      attribute type { "bullet" | "section" },
      attribute rend { "dots" | "numbers" | "letters" }?,
      head?,
      p?,
      element item { ( label | milestone | paragraph | list )+ }+
   }

4.8. macro.limitedContent

macro.limitedContent(paragraph content) defines the content of prose elements that are not used for transcription of extant materials. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
desc
Content model 
<content>
<alternatemaxOccurs="unbounded"
minOccurs="0">
<textNode/>
<classRefkey="model.limitedPhrase"/>
<classRefkey="model.inter"/>
</alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
macro.limitedContent = ( text | model.limitedPhrase | model.inter )*

4.9. macro.paraContent

macro.paraContent(paragraph content) defines the content of paragraphs and similar elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
canonDef endnote mantra modPassage orig p ref title
Declaration 
macro.paraContent =
   (
      text
    |model.gLike
    |model.phrase
    |model.inter
    |model.global
    |model.lLike
    |lg
    |mantra
    |space
    |span
    |modPassage
    |canonDef
    |ref-canonical
    |ref-other
   )*

4.10. macro.phraseSeq

macro.phraseSeq(phrase sequence) defines a sequence of character data and phrase-level elements. [1.4.1. Standard Content Models]
Module tei
Used by
author biblScope distinct editor expan foreign label publisher term
Declaration 
macro.phraseSeq =
   (
      text
    |model.gLike
    |model.attributable
    |model.phrase
    |model.global
    |ref-canonical
    |ref-other
   )*

4.11. macro.specialPara

macro.specialPara('special' paragraph content) defines the content model of elements such as notes or list items, which either contain a series of component-level elements or else have the same structure as a paragraph, containing a series of phrase-level and inter-level elements. [1.3. The TEI Class System]
Module tei
Used by
item note q
Declaration 
macro.specialPara =
   (
      text
    |model.gLike
    |model.phrase
    |model.inter
    |model.divPart
    |model.global
    |mantra
    |modPassage
    |space
    |canonDef
    |ref-other
    |ref-canonical
   )*

4.12. paragraph

paragraph
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
list-in-front-body publicationStmt section-content
Declaration 
paragraph =
   element p
   {
      attribute tid { xsd:integer },
      attribute type { "sponsor" }?,
      attribute rend { "mantra" | "ignoreGlossary" }?,
      (
         text
       |title
       |ptr
       |endnote
       |foreign
       |ref-canonical
       |ref-other
       |emph
       |distinct
       |q
       |lb
       |hi
       |label
       |mantra
       |modPassage
       |space
       |canonDef
       |code
       |element term
         {
            attribute type { "ignore" }?,
            attribute ref { text }?,
            ( foreign* | text )+
         }
      )+
   }

4.13. ref-canonical

ref-canonical
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
l macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara paragraph trailer
Declaration 
ref-canonical =
   element ref
   {
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      attribute type { "folio" | "volume" },
      attribute cRef { text },
      attribute key { text }?,
      attribute rend { "blank" | "hidden" }?,
      attribute work { text }?,
      attribute page { text }?,
      text
   }

4.14. ref-other

ref-other
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back bibl-section-content endnote l macro.paraContent macro.phraseSeq macro.specialPara paragraph trailer
Declaration 
ref-other =
   element ref
   {
      attribute type { "bampo" | "sanskrit" | "chinese" }?,
      attribute rend { "hidden" | "pending" }?,
      attribute cRef { text }?,
      attribute target { text }?,
      attribute inst { text }?,
      attribute work { text }?,
      attribute key { text }?,
      text
   }

4.15. section-content

section-content
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back body front translation-chapter translation-section translation-subsection-lv10 translation-subsection-lv11 translation-subsection-lv3 translation-subsection-lv4 translation-subsection-lv5 translation-subsection-lv6 translation-subsection-lv7 translation-subsection-lv8 translation-subsection-lv9
Declaration 
section-content =
   (
      milestone
    |paragraph
    |q
    |head
    |lb
    |lg
    |list-in-front-body
    |table
    |label
    |trailer
    |media
   )*

4.16. translation-chapter

translation-chapter
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back body translation-section
Declaration 
translation-chapter =
   element div
   {
      attribute type { "chapter" },
      attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
      attribute rend { text }?,
      attribute prefix { text }?,
      element head
      {
         attribute type { "chapter" },
         attribute tid { text }?,
         attribute key { text }?,
         (
            string { minLength = "1" }
          |( ( endnote | title | foreign )+ & text )
         )
      },
      (
         element head { attribute type { "chapterTitle" }, head-content }
       |element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }
      )*,
      section-content,
      translation-subsection-lv3*
   }

4.17. translation-section

translation-section
Module derived-module-NewODD
Used by
back body front
Declaration 
translation-section =
   element div
   {
      translation-section-head-content,
      section-content,
      ( translation-subsection-lv3* | translation-chapter* )
   }

4.18. translation-section-head-content

translation-section-head-content

Used by
translation-section translation-subsection-lv10 translation-subsection-lv11 translation-subsection-lv3 translation-subsection-lv4 translation-subsection-lv5 translation-subsection-lv6 translation-subsection-lv7 translation-subsection-lv8 translation-subsection-lv9

translation-section-head-content =
   attribute type { "section" },
   attribute [http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace]id { xsd:ID },
   attribute rend { text }?,
   attribute prefix { text }?,
   element head { attribute type { "section" }, head-content }*+

5. Datatypes

5.1. teidata.certainty

teidata.certaintydefines the range of attribute values expressing a degree of certainty.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model 
<content>
<valListtype="closed">
<valItemident="high"/>
<valItemident="medium"/>
<valItemident="low"/>
<valItemident="unknown"/>
</valList>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.certainty = "high" | "medium" | "low" | "unknown"
Note

Certainty may be expressed by one of the predefined symbolic values high, medium, or low. The value unknown should be used in cases where the encoder does not wish to assert an opinion about the matter.

5.2. teidata.count

teidata.countdefines the range of attribute values used for a non-negative integer value used as a count.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="nonNegativeInteger"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.count = xsd:nonNegativeInteger
Note

Any positive integer value or zero is permitted

5.3. teidata.duration.iso

teidata.duration.isodefines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="token"
restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.duration.iso = token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
Example
<timedur-iso="PT0,75H">three-quarters of an hour</time>
Example
<datedur-iso="P1,5D">a day and a half</date>
Example
<datedur-iso="P14D">a fortnight</date>
Example
<timedur-iso="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the last, which may have a decimal component (using either . or , as the decimal point; the latter is preferred). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first time number-letter pair.

For complete details, see ISO 8601 Data elements and interchange formats Information interchange Representation of dates and times.

5.4. teidata.duration.w3c

teidata.duration.w3cdefines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="duration"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.duration.w3c = xsd:duration
Example
<timedur="PT45M">forty-five minutes</time>
Example
<datedur="P1DT12H">a day and a half</date>
Example
<datedur="P7D">a week</date>
Example
<timedur="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
Note

A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the S number, which may have a decimal component (using . as the decimal point). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first time number-letter pair.

For complete details, see the W3C specification.

5.5. teidata.enumerated

teidata.enumerateddefines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
