Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@role
  • bibl/@type
  • cell/@role
  • desc/@type
  • distinct/@type
  • div/@type
  • editor/@role
  • gloss/@type
  • head/@type
  • lg/@type
  • milestone/@unit
  • note/@place
  • q/@type
  • ref/@type
  • row/@role
  • term/@type
  • title/@type
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefkey="teidata.word"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.enumerated = teidata.word
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

Typically, the list of documented possibilities will be provided (or exemplified) by a value list in the associated attribute specification, expressed with a <valList> element.

5.6. teidata.name

teidata.namedefines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="Name"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.name = xsd:Name
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see https://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name ): for example they cannot include whitespace or begin with digits.

5.7. teidata.namespace

teidata.namespacedefines the range of attribute values used to indicate XML namespaces as defined by the W3C Namespaces in XML Technical Recommendation.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="anyURI"restriction="\S*"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.namespace = xsd:anyURI { pattern = "\S*" }
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax

5.8. teidata.numeric

teidata.numericdefines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<alternate>
<dataRefname="double"/>
<dataRefname="token"
restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
<dataRefname="decimal"/>
</alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal
Note

Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, E notation, a variant of exponential notation, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

5.9. teidata.pattern

teidata.patterndefines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="token"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.pattern = token
Note
A regular expression, often called a pattern, is an expression that describes a set of strings. They are usually used to give a concise description of a set, without having to list all elements. For example, the set containing the three strings Handel, Hndel, and Haendel can be described by the pattern H(|ae?)ndel (or alternatively, it is said that the pattern H(|ae?)ndel matches each of the three strings)
Wikipedia

This TEI datatype is mapped to the XSD token datatype, and may therefore contain any string of characters. However, it is recommended that the value used conform to the particular flavour of regular expression syntax supported by XSD Schema.

5.10. teidata.pointer

teidata.pointerdefines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@ref
  • catRef/@scheme
  • editor/@ref
  • media/@url
  • ptr/@target
  • term/@ref
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="anyURI"restriction="\S+"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI { pattern = "\S+" }
Note

The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://.-./ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

5.11. teidata.probCert

teidata.probCertdefines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<alternate>
<dataRefkey="teidata.probability"/>
<dataRefkey="teidata.certainty"/>
</alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.probCert = teidata.probability | teidata.certainty

5.12. teidata.probability

teidata.probabilitydefines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.probCert
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="double"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.probability = xsd:double
Note

Probability is expressed as a real number between 0 and 1; 0 representing certainly false and 1 representing certainly true.

5.13. teidata.replacement

teidata.replacementdefines attribute values which contain a replacement template.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<textNode/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.replacement = text

5.14. teidata.temporal.working

teidata.temporal.workingdefines the range of values, conforming to the W3C XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition specification, expressing a date or a date and a time within the working life of the document.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<alternate>
<dataRefname="date"
restriction="(19[789][0-9]|[2-9][0-9]{3}).*"/>
<dataRefname="dateTime"
restriction="(19[789][0-9]|[2-9][0-9]{3}).*"/>
</alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.temporal.working =
   xsd:date { pattern = "(19[789][0-9]|[2-9][0-9]{3}).*" }
 |xsd:dateTime { pattern = "(19[789][0-9]|[2-9][0-9]{3}).*" }
Note

If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

The earliest time expressable with this datatype is 01 January 1970 (the Unix Epoch), which could be written as either 1970-01-01 or 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.

5.15. teidata.text

teidata.textdefines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of Unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • author/@key
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="string"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.text = string
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single token in which whitespace and other punctuation characters are permitted.

5.16. teidata.truthValue

teidata.truthValuedefines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="boolean"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.truthValue = xsd:boolean
Note

The possible values of this datatype are 1 or true, or 0 or false.

This datatype applies only for cases where uncertainty is inappropriate; if the attribute concerned may have a value other than true or false, e.g. unknown, or inapplicable, it should have the extended version of this datatype: teidata.xTruthValue.

5.17. teidata.unboundedCount

teidata.unboundedCountdefines the range of values used for a counting number or the string unbounded for infinity.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<alternate>
<dataRefname="nonNegativeInteger"/>
<valListtype="closed">
<valItemident="unbounded"/>
</valList>
</alternate>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.unboundedCount = xsd:nonNegativeInteger | ( "unbounded" )

5.18. teidata.version

teidata.versiondefines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
Module tei
Used by
Element:
  • TEI/@version
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="token"
restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }
Note

The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number ( http://unicode.org/versions/ ). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.

5.19. teidata.versionNumber

teidata.versionNumberdefines the range of attribute values used for version numbers.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="token"
restriction="[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.versionNumber =
   token { pattern = "[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}" }

5.20. teidata.word

teidata.worddefines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
Module tei
Used by
teidata.enumerated Element:
  • code/@lang
  • div/@rend
  • mantra/@rend
  • ref/@rend
  • title/@rend
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="token"
restriction="[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.word = token { pattern = "[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+" }
Note

Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

5.21. teidata.xmlName

teidata.xmlNamedefines attribute values which contain an XML name.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<dataRefname="NCName"/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.xmlName = xsd:NCName
Note

The rules defining an XML name form a part of the XML Specification.

5.22. teidata.xpath

teidata.xpathdefines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.
Module tei
Used by
Content model 
<content>
<textNode/>
</content>
Declaration 
teidata.xpath = text
Note

Any XPath expression using the syntax defined in 6.2..

When writing programs that evaluate XPath expressions, programmers should be mindful of the possibility of malicious code injection attacks. For further information about XPath injection attacks, see the article at OWASP.

Appendix A Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors

Following below are complete step-by-step guidelines for marking up 84000 TEI. To reference how the markup stage is integrated with the entire 84000 workflow, here is link to the Editorial and Publications Workflow document.

Appendix A.1 Check the MS Word Document from Project Management

According to our current workflow, when a text is passed to markup it should be already uploaded to project management. First click on the "Search" tab and locate the file using the Toh number. Once you have found the text click on "edit headers", from there you can expand the "submissions" section (The TEI will be generated from this same screen as well, see below). From here you may click on the document and download it in order to check the document from MS Word. The copyeditors will have entered most of the proper style tags for foreign terms, verses, some of the mantra markup, and so forth. However, when you begin a text it is important to double check the work and make sure the text has been entered properly into the template. Also, sometimes you may be asked to apply the style tags into the template yourself, so as you continue to edit TEI markup, you should occasionally read the instructions in the copy editor's template and try to become familiar with them (The latest version of the copy editor's template may be downloaded here). A lot of the tags are set up to be tagged with character and paragraph styles from the template and automatically converted by a script into to correct markup. However, the copy editors may occasionally make some mistakes, and being familiar with the template will help you correct them and inform the copy editors of any issues. Remember, sections can always be corrected from the template, passed through the script again, and pasted into the final TEI so keep the original word document open for reference while you work.

When checking the document please follow check that the following is applied in the DOCX:

  • In general you can corraborate with the instructions written in the template.
  • Check that the text has tagged the appropriate sections using the "Heading 1, 2, 3, etc" headings. The "Heading 1 and 2" styles should be embedded in the template, but the copy editor will add more headings as is needed. All of these headings will trigger the script to generate section divisions in the TEI. MS Word has heading styles up to "Heading 9". In the rare case that more are needed, hard tags will be used e.g. "<level 10 header>", which will need to be applied manually from Oxygen. If the editors have removed one of the default headings by accident it may cause a section to be missing in the converted TEI. One way to check is to look in under the view tab in MS word and check the box that says "Navigation Pane". This should show you an outline of the text from a side window, which should follow a layout according to the heading styles. "The Introduction" and "The Translation" should either be filled with subsections or just one default subsection that says "Main Section".
  • All the italics have been applied with the various character styles, "foreign-", "title-", etc. (don't worry though, if you miss some, those italics will be given a <fix> tag by the script).
  • Because the markup for mantras has become a bit complicated, we have provided the copy editors an "Option Two" for applying style tags to all the mantras. This instruction was given in case differentiating the different "mantra" styles becomes too distracting from the actual copy editing work. Under "Option Two," the copy editor will tag all of the mantra italics with the character style "Mantra-Other" and you will need to distinguish and apply the appropriate markup to the mantras. You can do this either now, while you are checking the template, or you can pass the template through the script as it is and all the mantras will be tagged <mantra type="input type" xml:lang="input language"> and you can mark them up in the XML. However, I recommend doing this from the template as it will be faster. You can quickly find all the "Mantra-Other" tags by doing an "advanced find and replace" and click on the Format --> "Style" in the search dialog box. Leave the search bar empty and you can quickly go through all the "Mantra-Other" styles in the entire template and apply the correct style from the style pane. See instructions for the mantra markup in the template II. MANTRAS, pp 35, or see the full documentation for the mantra markup here in Appendix B Topics Mantras.
  • All the verses have the "verse" paragraph style applied, and they are formatted correctly with line breaks between lines and paragraph breaks between stanzas (change the display settings to show paragraph marks and line breaks so you can see more clearly whether they are formatted correctly).
  • In some cases the copy editors may have left comments for the markup editors with the MS Word comments feature. The script will convert these into <note> elements that will have the "place" attribute with the value of "comment_from_copyeditor_to_markup_editor." I have intentionally set this up to be highlighted by the schema as an error, so that the copy editors may highlight any unusual formatting or other issues that need to be addressed by the markup editors. You may leave these in and address them as you work on the XML or alternatively keep a backup of the .docx and reference the comments from there. If you don't want to see them in the XML, make a backup of the .docx and select "Delete All Comments in the Document" from the review pane in Word before sending the document through the conversion script.

If the document looks good, you can go ahead and run the script, otherwise make corrections and upload the document again. If so, please use the exact same file name but add "-v2" or "-v3"... etc. for any subsequent versions for example: "T747-bhutadamara-for-markup-apr-16-2020-v2". Upload it to project management with the /Submissions.

Don't worry, you can always go back and do this again later on if you notice some problem in the DOCX.

Appendix A.2 Transform the New DOCX To TEI-XML

Running the Document through the Conversion Script:
  • Again using the "/Submissions" tab in Project Management, click on the document you wish to run through the script, and in the next panel, there will be a checklist on the right side of the screen. Check the "generate TEI" box, and then click save. The app will perform the conversion and the output .xml file can be found in the 84000 Collaboration/apps/84000-import-data folder. There will be a unique folder created with the name of the texts xml:id number. Note that you can convert the glossary through this submissions form as well (although this should be done later after checking the document, see Appendix: Transform and Edit the Glossary.
  • Occasionally the app may be down or the project management page may give you a permissions error. If it says that permission is denied you should email the lead technician who handles the server's permissions (Dominic). Alternatively, it is also possible to convert the word .docx created in the template through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and run our own .xslt script on the document. The .xslt script is in apps/84000-import-data/xsl. (Instructions for running an .xslt script can be found in the Appendix: Guidefor Using an XSLT Conversion Script)
Checking the XML Conversion before You Begin Editing:
  • This should create a file that is closer to what we want. However, the script is definitely not perfect, and many sections will need some reworking.
  • If the "verse" styles were applied appropriately in the template, then the script should put them correctly into <lg> and <l> elements. It should also preserve and convert any italic markup within the verses. The script is able to do both because in MS Word the "verse" is a paragraph style and all the italic markups are character styles. However, for the script to work properly the individual lines of verse need to be separated by line breaks, and the stanzas themselves need to be separated by paragraph breaks. There are instructions for how to do this in the template, but this process can be a bit finicky, so you should double check some of the verses to make sure the conversion has worked properly. Refer to the section on the <lg> element to see how verses need to be formatted.
  • Another note about the script to keep in mind is that the script is designed to automatically create divisions with <div> elements in the markup whenever the copy editors use the "heading 1," "heading 2," etc. styles in the template (up to "heading 9"). This will create the proper levels of <div>s. Any tenth level <div>s or further should be placed into tags by the copy editor and you will need to create the <div>s manually when you edit the XML. Occasionally, the copy editor will put a heading into the "heading 1" or "heading 2" style but they will mistakenly leave the paragraph break at the end of the heading's text in the "normal" style. The script generates the <div> elements according to these paragraph breaks, so in this case, it will not create the proper division. Usually it is easy enough to correct these in either the template .docx or in the .xml, but in some cases it may save you some time if you can identify and fix them before the conversion. For example, this happened in the bibliography of a text, and because the bibliography entries were nested with one <div> instead of two, the script rendered them into <p> elements instead of <bibl> elements as is required.
  • The script has a section for making appendices, which should appear in the <back> after the bibliography. However, since not all the texts have appendices, and since appendices could appear in many different forms such as lists, outlines, Sanskrit sources, etc., the script only converts these into the minimal default paragraphs or verses. You may need to reformat the markup in the section extensively or paste it in from the word file and mark it up from there. If there are more appendices in the future, or a particularly large appendix that needs to be extensively edited, we will develop the script to convert the appendices in a more detailed way.
  • If there is some unusual formatting or other issue that is preventing the script from converting the text properly, one strategy for isolating the problem is to divide the text into three pieces (front material, body, and back material), convert each section one be one, and then paste them into the final .xml. In this case do the conversion through oxGarage (Instructions for this are found in the Appendix: Guidefor Using an XSLT Conversion Script).

Appendix A.3 Merging the Converted XML into the Placeholder File

Merge the Converted XML into the Placeholder File:
  • When you have finished converting the document into an TEI-XML file, it is time to transfer it into the translations folder. There should already be a placeholder file for each of the Kangyur and Tengyur texts. Go to 84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > tei > translations, and you will see the "kangyur" and "tengyur" folders. Each of these folders in turn contain a "placeholders" folder and a "translations" folder. Find the placeholder file right click and select "cut" then move it into the sibling "translations" folder by right and select "paste" (don't use "copy" and "paste" as this will reset the files permissions).
  • Now please change the file name to reflect what has been given as an English title by the translator. The previous title was translated before the project, so we want the filename to be consistent with what the translator has given. ***Important: please don't use any apostrophes or diacritics in the filename and remove any that happen to be there, as these will create problems for the server.
  • You can then begin pasting the text from the XML you just converted into the placeholder text. The placeholder files usually just contain the <teiHeader>, however, most of this is important information and should not be overwritten. The converted XML will have directions in the form of comments, which will tell you specifically what elements within the teiHeader need to be added to the placeholder, and which to be left as is. In general, try to preserve all pertinent information from both sources, and if there is any data that seems to be contradictory, comment out the additional data and make a note of this in your final list of notes and issues.
  • The placeholder's <titleStmt> will require some extra attention; this contains the original collection of titles given to texts when the 84000 project first begin. However, when translations for these texts are made there will likely be many changes that need to be applied to the various titles. There may be additional alternative titles discovered through the translator's research, but there may be some alternative titles found in the placeholder file that the translator did not notice. So when merging the <titleStmt> in the converted XML with the placehoder please use the following protocol:
    • Update any English title to the one used by the translator found in the converted XML.
    • Preserve any alternative titles found in either the converted XML or the placeholder file. Alternative titles should be labeled type="otherTitle"
    • Make sure that the Sanskrit and Tibetan short titles, i.e., "otherTitles", are consistent with the English title in terms of the prensense of the final "" or"-stra". These should be removed if the word "Stra" isn't also found in the corresponding short English title. This presence or absence of "Stra" is not significant enough to warrant adding an additional "alternativeTitle"
    • Sanskrit Titles should have the first letter capitalized.
    • There should be a minimum of nine titles: 4 Main Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), 4 Long Titles (Sanskrit, Tibetan, Wylie, English), and 1 Chinese. Any additional variant <title>s (whether coming from the converted file or already present in the placeholder) should be added after this as type="otherTitle". The actual order of the titles doesn't matter because the parser will display them in the same order no matter what order the XML is in, but if one or more of the nine default titles are not present, leave an empty element there as a place holder, e.g., <title type="otherTitle" xml:lang="zh"/>. Here is an example of the nine titles from Toh 83:
      <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</title> <titletype="mainTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bhadraplarehiparipcch</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="bo"></title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Bo-Ltn">phags pa tshong dpon bzang skyong gis zhus pa zhes bya ba theg pa chen poi mdo</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="en">The Noble Mahyna Stra The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</title> <titletype="longTitle"xml:lang="Sa-Ltn">ryabhadraplarehiparipcchnmamahynastra</title> <titletype="otherTitle"xml:lang="zh"/>
      (See how this is displayed in the Reading Room)
    • Any straight single quote marks found in the Wylie should be changed to right curling ones. Note that all the Wylie in the placeholder titles will need to be changed because they have been left as straight quote marks in order to make them compatible with research databases like BDRC when the translator is in the research phase for that text. However, in our publications we only use curled ones.
    • The Tibetan Unicode titles "bo" should end with a shad but the Wylie titles "Bo-Ltn" should NOT end with a shad or backslash.
    • After the titles the main translator or translator group will be listed in an <author role="translatorMain"> along with the phrase "translated by... under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha." This should be added below the last title it should also have a ref element which should already be assigned ahead of time from project managent. For example in Toh 83, the main translator looks like this:
      <authorref="contributors.xml#team-16" role="translatorMain"> Translated by Karen Liljenberg and Ulrich Pagel<lb/> under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha</author>
      It is important that it follows this format along with the accompanying statement as this will be displayed on the cover page in the Reading Room.
  • You can reference title statement found in the TEI of Toh 83 if you need a template to work from.
  • Also check the original word document for additional titles as the conversion script is quite rigid, and some of them might disappear if they were not entered properly.
  • Occasionally, there will be a Chinese summary in the placeholder file, this should be merged into the TEI by placing the Chinese summary in its own <div> immediately after the English summary, for example:
    <divtype="summary"> <headtid="699"type="summary">Summary</head> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-064-001-1"/> <ptid="1">On Gayra Hill, Buddha kyamuni is visited by a great gathering of bodhisattvas... [English Summary Here] </p> </div> <divtype="summary"xml:lang="zh"> <ptid="711">... [Chinese Summary Here]</p> </div>
    The Chinese will not be displayed in the English web display, but will appear in the Chinese catalog.
  • Note if Chinese characters are found in the sponsorship statement in the Acknowledgements: Sponsors are asked for what statement they would like give in the publication. Occasionally, these may be given in Chinese characters without translation or transliteration. For example here in Toh 543. So if you see this in the acknowledgements it is perfectly acceptable if that is what the sponsors request. Although, if you see it like this do make a note in the Reading Room Revisions sheet to confirm their choice in the final proofing stage.
  • Following the <titleStmt>, there are other sections in the teiHeader that need to be merged with those found in the placeholder file. There are specific instructions for merging each section of the teiHeader that will be provided as comments in the TEI file that was converted by the script. Please read through and follow these comments, which will tell you how to merge each section.
  • Since the merge process is a bit complicated, you may want to refer to the <teiHeader> in Toh 83 for reference. All the headers should follow the same format that has been used in Toh 83.
  • After the <teiHeader> is merged, the remaining text can be directly pasted into the placeholder file and the rest of the markup of can be completed here.
A Note about Text Status and Project Management:
  • Note that the teiHeader can also be edited from the project management page. The forms found on the project management page can edit the elements in the TEI; this way editors and administration can edit these fields without access to Oxygen.
  • The text "status" can be changed from project management, but it can also be edited directly in the TEI as an attribute in the <publicationStmt>. Through the whole markup phase the text status should be "2.a" indicating that markup is in process. It should already be at that stage when arriving in markup. Note that it needs to be at stage "2.a" or later for the text to be displayed from the Utilities page. When you are completed with all the markup, it will be reviewed one more time by the lead markup editor and then they will update the status to "2", ("Markup Completed, and awaiting final proofing before release").

Appendix A.4 Edit the XML

Appendix A.4.1 Apply the Schema:

  • The schema should already be applied to the placeholder file, but if you need to apply the schema directly it is located in 84000 Collaboration > apps > 84000-data > schema > current > translation.rng. You will see any schema errors as red bars on the right column in the oXygen window. Checking the schema is the best way to see if the XML is going to work correctly in the parser. If later on you have trouble saving to the database, or if you can save to the database but the web page does not display the text, then start by checking for schema errors in oXygen. If it says that there is an error where you dont think there is really an error, but you need to check the XML on the web display, you can comment-out that section with comment tags:
    <!-- --> (or highlight and press Ctrl-Shift , on PC or Command-Shift "m" on mac). Then you will be able to temporarily block all the seeming schema errors to help identify the problem.
  • You will initially see many schema errors for some missing attributes such as "xml:id"s and "tid"s. Note that all "xml:id" attributes, "tid" attributes in the <p> elements, and "index" attributes in the <note> elements will be added automatically when you save and reload the XML, so you don't need to worry about adding these. However, in the <teiHeader> within the <publicationStmt> there is an element for the id number for the text, <idno>. This should have been already present in the placeholder folder, however if it is missing retrieve it from your manager and enter it in manually as this is needed to generate all the xml:id attributes in the text.
  • In case there is an error in any of the "xml:id" or "tid" attributes due to duplicates, then you can regenerate them by deleting any problematic ones, saving the file, and then re-opening. The "xml:id" and "tid" will be generated wherever they are missing. If not, email the lead technician and they will make sure they are regenerated. It is fine if the "xml:id" attributes are not in order as long as they each have a unique value.

Appendix A.4.2 Some General Guidelines for Editing the XML:

  • While editing the XML, I usually use a previously edited and published TEI document as a model to make sure everything is formatted in the same way. This can be helpful, especially if this is your first time marking up a text or if you haven't done the markup for some time. Toh 83 is our go to as the standard for markup. This is a simple text, one of our earliest publications, and the first place we look when assuring that our markup is consistent. Toh 83 is a good standard, although because it is a simple text it may not have references for how to deal with the markup used in special cases. Here are some other texts with published TEI, which you may refer to for specific markup situations:
    • For a text containing a lot of mantras: see Toh 431
    • For a text with a complex outline (containing 6+ levels of <div>s): see Toh 1-1
    • For a text with extensive Chinese quotations in the notes: see Toh 61
    Also, if you are looking for a specific element try right clicking on the published "translations" folder and searching for a specific example to reference, e.g., "<table" to find a reference of the <table> element.
  • In general, while going through the text, it is important to periodically refer back to the .docx you received from the copy editor. If the document has an unusually formatted outline, some portions of text may be lost in the XSLT conversion. A good way to check this is to open the original .docx and look at the outline of the text (on PC go to View and check the box that says Show Navigation Pane; on Mac go to View > Sidebar > Document Map Pane; this might be different for other versions of Word). For example, if there are any fourth-level headers or extra divisions in the summary or acknowledgements, these sections may disappear. It is particularly good to check the front material and the bibliography for anything unusual.
  • The template should generate a placeholder for sponsorship in the Acknowledgements section (e.g. "[Sponsored by XXXXX.]"), this is just a placeholder for the sponsor so the editors and Line remember to check the sponsorship with Jing Rui before publication. Please leave it as is unless instructions from management say otherwise.
  • The acknowledgements section should be formatted in the following manner:
    • Main translator acknowledgements
    • Supervision of 84000 acknowledgement
    • <break> (convert this to an <lb> element)
    • Sponsorship acknowledgement
    for example:
    <ptid="4">Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the supervision of Chokyi Nyima Rinpoche. The translation was produced by Thomas Doctor with help from Benjamin Collet-Cassart and Timothy Hinkle. Thomas also wrote the introduction. Andreas Doctor checked the translation against the Tibetan and edited the text. David Higgins subsequently reviewed the translation and made further edits. Wiesiek Mical assisted by reviewing numerous passages against the available Sanskrit sources. Robert Kritzer generously shared several unpublished articles on the text with us and Vesna Wallace and Mitsuyo Demoto kindly gave us access to drafts of their critical Sanskrit editions of chapters 1 and 3, respectively. </p> <ptid="6">The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.</p> <lb/> <ptid="5">[Sponsored by XXXXX.]</p>
  • When you first get to the <body> of the text, you may notice that the title has been repeated with two lines containing separate <p> and <milestone> tags. For example:
    <body> <divtype="translation"> <headtype="translation"> The Translation </head> <headtype="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Stra</head> <headtype="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p> The Noble Great Vehicle Stra </p> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p> Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality </p> <!--...body of the text...--> </div> </body>
    The reason for this, is the script has a safeguard to display any text within the first main <div> but not included in the first second level <div>. A not ideal consequence of this safeguard results in this repetition of the first two lines, which simply needed to be deleted manually. So the above example should be edited to look as follows:
    <body> <divtype="translation"> <headtype="translation"> The Translation </head> <headtype="titleHon">The Noble Great Vehicle Stra</head> <headtype="titleMain">Distinguishing Between Phenomena and Reality</head> <!--...body of the text...--> </div> </body>
  • If either one of the introduction, main translation, and/or bibliography have only one section you will probably see this heading at the beginning of their second level <div> element:
    <head>Main Section</head>
    This is actually a placeholder from the template and should be removed, as the heading from the previous <div> element will provide the heading "Introduction" or "The Translation."
  • Most Kangyur texts begin with a short homage, typically this should be followed by a line break <lb> between the homage and the beginning of the text, which needs to be added manually:
    <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-044-005-11"/> <ptid="13"> <refcRef="F.104.b"type="folio"/> Homage to all the buddhas and bodhisattvas! </p> <lb/> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-044-005-12"/> <ptid="14">Thus have I heard at one time. <!--...--> </p>
    (Click here to see in Reading Room display) Occasionally there may be a long homage that necessitates its own section. In this case it may be appropriate to create a <div> for the homage itself. The <div> and its accompanying <head> should both be type="homage". See for example in Toh 138:
    <divtype="homage"> <headtid="995"type="homage">Homage</head> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-056-006-23"/> <ptid="27"> <refcRef="F.187.b"type="folio"/> <refcRef="B1"type="bampo"/>Homage to the thus-gone Splendorous with the Gentle Glow of Light and Fragrance!</p> <lb/> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-056-006-1876"/> <ptid="28">Homage to the one with the melodious voice of Mahbrahm!</p> <lb/> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-056-006-25"/> <ptid="29">Having paid homage to him, <!--...etc...--> </p> <!--...etc...--> </div>
    (Click here to see in Reading Room display)
  • If there were any italics that were missed in the copy editing phase, they will appear with a schema error in an element called "fix." You will need to manually fix these and replace them with the appropriate element, whether it be <foreign>, <title>, <distinct>, <mantra> etc. Sometimes these may be just italicized punctuation that the copy editor or author made by mistake, in which case you can go ahead and remove these tags.
  • Any <foreign> or <title> tags that are not tagged as English, Sanskrit, or Tibetan language, will need to have their @xml:lang tag entered in manually. These will all be highlighted by a schema error for the value of @xml:lang="Input_Language". In each case please apply the appropriate language code (the list of language codes can be referenced in the documentation for the <foreign> element.
  • Check that all mantras have been properly tagged. Note, that any mantras that have fragments of them written in more than one languages--usually English with Sanskrit seed syllables but this may also include Sanskrit/Tibetan mixed mantras--will be marked as such in the template and be converted to <foreign type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra">. They will appear as errors in the schema which is a signal for you to wrap the complete mantra in a <mantra xml:lang="mixed"> element. Then the @type="Fragment-in-MixedMantra" can be removed with the refactoring tool once they are all wrapped. <mantra>s need to be tagged in precise way, please see Appendix B Topics: Mantras for details on how to markup the mantras.
  • Double check that the tag <hi rend="small-caps"> is used for any small capital letters in the text. This includes any abbreviations for CE ("Common Era") or BCE ("Before Common Era") in dates. Note that the lowercase letter needs to be used for small-caps, for example:
    In the year 2000 <hirend="small-caps">bce</hi>
    Then the parser will render this as small capital "BCE".
    (If for some reason you ever need to add diacritics to small-caps, see details about this in the documentation for the <hi> element).
  • Note that some of the Kangyur sigla in the abbreviations and notes use subscript letters. For Kangyur sigla we use the Vienna system, which you can check the spelling here. Most of the sigla use a Capital letter followed by a lowercase one, but the sigla from the Peking Group, Mongolian, and Nyingma Kangyurs use a capital letter followed by subscript letters, and these second letters should have the <hi rend="subscript"> tag. Here either the lowercase or uppercase letter should be used according to the definitive sigla, for example:
    Peking 1737 PK = K<hirend="subscript">Q</hi>, rnying rgyud bris ma = G<hirend="subscript">bm</hi>.
    Do not use any unicode for the small caps or subscript such as "" or "" as this won't display consistently in the reading room for all browsers. The script should convert all small-caps and subscript from the template with the proper tag, if "small-caps" and "subscript" were applied in the template using MS Words Font dialog (Format > Font), but these should be double checked in the XML.
  • Look for any weird tags that shouldn't be there like "type="endnote text"" or any other relics from the oxgarage/script conversion.
  • Look for any mistakes: typos, mislabeled tags, etc.
  • Note that ellipses were previously made with three periods and non-breaking spaces (U+00A0) before each of the periods. However, we have updated our standard to instead use a single Unicode ellipsis character: There is occasionally some ambiguity as to whether punctuation coming before/after an ellipsis should have a space; documentation for how to determine the proper standard for such punctuation is found here.
  • As you do any major work on the text, it is a good idea to occasionally update the version number as a reference for file backups. For guidelines on how and when to do this, see Appendix: Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document.

Appendix A.4.3 Editing Folio, Bampo, and Other Page References in the XML:

  • All the references such as [F.100.a], etc. need to be entered into <ref> elements with the "cRef" attribute, thus [F.100.a] should look like this:
    <refcRef="F.100.a"type="folio"/>
    Note that this is the standard we are using for all folio references: it should be an "F" followed by a period, a number, another period, and the letter "a" or "b." To put the bracketed folios into the <ref> element I usually use a search and replace with regular expressions. To do this open a find and replace box, check the "Regular Expressions" box and search for:
    \[(F\.\d+\.[ab])\]
    Replace with:
    <refcRef="$1"type="folio"/>
    Or if they forgot to add the second period before that "a" or "b," like "[F.100a]", then search for:
    \[(F\.\d+)([ab])\]
    And replace with:
    <refcRef="$1.$2"type="folio"/>
    Another situation you might see is double folios for duplicate Toh versions such as, "[(Toh 674) F.212.a] [(Toh 849) F.58.a]". Since you need to copy over the Toh # as the key, you can do that with a regular expression like this, search:
    \[\(Toh(\d+)\)(F\.\d+\.[ab])\]
    And replace:
    <refcRef="$2"key="toh$1"type="folio"/>
    Regular expressions are very useful for such tasks, just be careful not to search and replace any text or markup you did not intend to. For example, the introduction of a text might quote a folio reference number in the same format in which it was applied in the body of the text, say "[F.100.a]". We definitely don't want this instance placed into a <ref> element, so be careful not to inadvertently replace it with a "replace all" command. If you aren't familiar with regular expressions this is a good reference website, and there are a lot of tutorials on youtube too.
  • Sometimes there are other reference numbers used within the texts such as bampo numbers or page numbers referencing another source. All of these should also be placed in <ref> elements using the following conventions:
    • Bampo references should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "bampo" and follow the format "B[bampo number]", for example:
      <refcRef="B1"type="bampo"/>
    • References to a Sanskrit, Chinese, or other source should be accompanied by the type attribute with the value "sanskrit", "chinese" etc. Typically curly brackets should be used to differentiate the Sanskrit or Chinese references from the Tibetan ones. Because the parser automatically generates square brackets around the cRef attribute, the inner node of the <ref> element should be used with typed curly brackets, for example:
      <reftype="sanskrit">{S1}</ref>
    • Note that whatever is placed in the @cRef attribute, will appear in square brackets in the reading room. Occasionally the author or editors may wish to hide a certain of reference number if they are deemed to be unnecessary for the general readership. In this case they may be given the attribute @rend="hidden", which will hide the reference in the reading room while still being marked in the TEI. For example this is done with some Sanskrit <ref>s in Toh 11:
      <refcRef="1"rend="hidden"type="sanskrit"/>

      Note, here it doesn't matter whether the cRef is used or the inner node is used since it will be rendered invisible in the Reading Room.

  • When a <ref> comes between two paragraphs, it is better to place it at the end of the preceding paragraph rather than the beginning of proceeding one, as this will be less distracting for the reader. The very first <ref>, however, must be placed at the beginning of the paragraph as there is no other choice.
  • When a large text spans multiple volumes a volume reference should be added at the beginning of the new volume just before the first folio reference of the new volume using the following format: <ref type="volume" cRef="V__">. For example in Toh 11, it spans to volume 32 at F.92.b:
    <refcRef="V32"type="volume"/> <refcRef="F.92.b"type="folio"/>
    See how this is displayed in Reading Room
    * Usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32. The volumes for the text will be marked in the <location>/<volume> element(s) in the located in the <sourceDesc>.
  • There are some texts that are duplicated in multiple sections of the Kangyur. For example The Prophecy of Sri_Mahadevi is found twice in the Kangyur as Toh. 193 and 739. Theses are both word for word exactly the same, but the folio references are going to be different for each duplicate version of the text. So in this situation we just use one TEI file, "061-014_toh193,739" but the folio references are differentiated with the key attribute which will relate each individual <ref> to the corresponding key that is declared within that version's <bibl> element found in the TEI's initial <sourceDesc>. For example, in 061-014_toh193,739's <sourceDesc>:
    <sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh193"type="text"> <ref>Toh 193</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 61 (mdo sde, tsa), folios 246.a250.b</biblScope> <authorrole="translatorTib">Unknown</author> <locationcount-pages="10" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="500"number="61" start-page="491"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC14668"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC11815" work="W22084"/> </bibl> <biblkey="toh739"type="text"> <ref>Toh 739</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 94 (rgyud bum, tsha), folios 230.a234.b</biblScope> <authorrole="translatorTib">Unknown</author> <locationcount-pages="10" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="468"number="94" start-page="459"/> </location> <idnoparent-id="O1JC114941JC21415"/> <idnosource-id="O1JC114941JC12480" work="W22084"/> </bibl> </sourceDesc>
    Then if you look at each individual folio references they will be differentiated by the key like this:
    ... <ptid="9"> <refcRef="F.246.a"key="toh193" type="folio"/> <refcRef="F.230.a"key="toh739" type="folio"/> Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. </p>
    Now the parser will only display the appropriate folio references, e.g., when you click on Toh. 193 it will show the references for Toh. 193 but not those for 739 and vice-versa. Sometimes the page breaks between the folios will be in the same place in the eKangyur but often they are different so you may need to go in and find them all manually if they were not written in by the translator.
  • As a final note on the subject of folio references, on rare occasions there are blank folio pages in the Deg appearing in the middle of texts. These blank pages will be matched with blank pages in the eKangyur; however, the reader generates a segment of preceding and following text from the nearest folio pages and this may be confusing to the reader when the folio reference is clicked in the web display. Therefore it is preferable to add a @rend="blank" attribute to any blank folios, which will suppress the link, and then add a note simply explaining that the page is blank. For example here is such a case in Toh 287:
    What difference is there <refcRef="F.82.b"rend="blank"type="folio" xml:id="UT22084-068-021-100028"/> <noteplace="end" xml:id="UT22084-068-021-102194">This folio of the Deg Kangyur is blank.</note> ...
    See how this is displayed in the Reading Room.

Appendix A.4.4 Editing Tags that were Entered from the Template with Angular Brackets < > :

  • There are a few special tags that copy editors have been instructed to enter into the template using angular brackets < and >. These include:
    • 1) Modular passages: <module starts> <module ends>
    • 2) Level ten sections or above: <level 10 div> </level 11 div> <level 12 div> </level 13 div> etc...
    • 3) Block quotes: <q> </q>
    • 4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts: <Reference Toh 9999 F.999.a>
    • 5) Double line breaks used to create a section break without a header <break>
    In each of these cases, in order to avoid nesting errors the angular brackets will be transformed by the script into their escape codes &lt; and &gt; respectively. In the xml editor these will appear in dark yellow type and can be easily searched for. Each should be addressed as follows:
    • 1) modular passages, for now should just be replaced with comments, although just the tags themselves not their content, e.g.:
      lt;modulestartsgt;Knowingandseeingall,lt;moduleendsgt;
      should be changed to
      <!--module starts-->Knowingandseeingall, <!--module ends-->
      Some day we will create markup for this but for now, they are noted in comments that can be searched later.
    • 2) Level ten sections or higher need <div> elements created for them along with any accompanying headers, e.g.:
      lt;level10divgt;Section1.2.1:VinayaRulesConcerningPetAlligatorslt;/level10divgt;
      should be changed to
      <divtype="section"> <headtype="section">Section 1.2.1: Vinaya Rules Concerning Pet Alligators</head> <!--The content of the section here.--> </div>
    • 3) Block quotes need to be changed into <q> elements. Any <p> or <lg> elements should be placed inside any <q> elements, e.g:
      <milestone/> lt;qgt; <milestone/> <lg> <l>Space has no abode;</l> <l> It is free from elaboration, and stainless.</l> <l>Your mind is the same as space,</l> <l>And you are free of any point of reference: </l> <l> I bow to you!</l> </lg> lt;/qgt;
      should be changed to
      <milestone/> <q> <lg> <l>Space has no abode;</l> <l> It is free from elaboration, and stainless.</l> <l>Your mind is the same as space,</l> <l>And you are free of any point of reference: </l> <l> I bow to you!</l> </lg> </q>
      Occasionally the copy editors might forget to put in tags for block quotes. Therefore, refer back to the original .docx if it seems like a section should be put into block quotes. Add a note to the final list of questions and issues if there is a section that was not set apart as a block quote that you believe should have.
    • 4) Links to other Kangyur/Tengyur texts should be created with <ref>, or if those texts are not yet published they should be given <ref> tags with the @rend="pending" attribute applied, e.g.:
      See <titlexml:lang="en">The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</title>lt;Reference Toh 0282gt;. See <titlexml:lang="en">The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines</title>lt;Reference Toh 4570gt; (a forthcoming 84000 publication).
      should be changed to
      See <title> <reftarget="http://read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html">The Questions of Bhadrapla the Merchant</ref> </title> See <titlexml:lang="en"> <refrend="pending" target="http://read.84000.co/translation/toh5001.html">The Perfection of Wisdom in One Million Lines</ref> </title> (a forthcoming 84000 publication).
      Please add these <ref> links and coded comments if they have been missed by the translator or copy editor. Note, that internal links are not made with the <ref> element, but rather with the <ptr> element. The compiled guidelines regarding how to create links are in the topics sections, see Appendix B Topics: Cross References and Links for more details.
    • 5) Replace lt;breakgt; with a simple <lb> tag.

Appendix A.4.5 Other Issues to Check For while Editing the XML:

  • Within the notes section of the text the template and script will create an abbreviations section even if there isn't one. If there isn't any abbreviations section in the original docx. you can delete the abbreviations header but leave the section for notes. It should just look like this:
    <divtype="notes"> <headtype="notes">Notes</head> </div>
  • If the translator used Kangyur sigla in the notes but didn't create an abbreviations section, you may need to add one. See details for this in Appendix B Topics: Abbreviations Section.
  • Any formal lists or outlines within the text should be marked up with the <list> element, which must also have the type attribute with the value "section" or "bullet." "Section" should be used for longer items of text, and it will render them with some vertical spacing between each item. "Bullet" should be used for shorter items and will create some horizontal indentation (it isn't necessary for there to be actual "bullets" in the list, this is just what we have named it). These types can be used in any combination to create an outline. For further details on outlines and some examples see Appendix B Topics: Outlines and Lists.
  • There may be times when a stanza of verse was missed and not placed into "verse" tags when being copy edited in the MS Word template. If that is the case you will notice each line of verse appearing in <p> tags rather than <l> tags. It is good to refer back to the original Word doc if you are in doubt, from there it should be clear according to the line breaks whether or not a stanza of verse was intended or not.
  • Occasionally there may be tables in a document. For instructions on how to markup tables see Appendix B Topics: Tables.
  • Check that all the <div> elements are marked up with the proper type attributes. See the documentation for the <div> element to see the list of acceptable values. Note that a "prologue" or "colophon" should be marked as such and not as a "section." Also, each <div> should be accompanied by a <head> that has its own matching type attribute; however, there is one exception to this, <div type="section"> may be left without a <head> if the author did not provide one, this will usually be the case in the Introduction, Main Translation, or Bibliography whenever there is just one section and by default it is placed into a second level <div type="section"> wrapped within a first level <div type="introduction"> or <div type="translation">. In this case the parser will read the <head>s from the main first level <div> and the second level <div type="section"> will not require an additional <head>.
  • The script doesn't distinguish between chapters and sections, so the type value for all the "chapters" needs to be applied manually. Also, "chapter"s should contain a <head> type="chapter" element with some kind of enumeration, i.e., "chapter one," "chapter two," etc. If there is a formal title it should be contained in a <head> type="chapterHead" element following the first <head>. For example:
    <divtype="chapter"> <headtype="chapter">Chapter 32</head> <headtype="chapterTitle">The Teaching on the Nature of All Phenomena</head> <!--...chapter text...--> </div>
  • Some texts have <trailer>s at the end of each chapter, for example in Toh. 11:
    <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-031-002-1980"/> <trailertid="3216">This completes the twenty-second chapter from the <titlexml:lang="en">Transcendent Perfection of Wisdom in Ten Thousand Lines</title>, entitled Cultivation.</trailer>
    Be default the script will convert every paragraph into a <p> element, so these <trailer>s should be manually applied if they appear at the end of each chapter. Please give each <trailer> its own milestone.
  • All of the trailers will be separated by a space and italicized in their entirety by the parser, so any <title>s that appear in the trailer should be giving curled quotations marks. You will probably need to add these as the italicization could likely have been unnoticed in the copy editing phase. e.g.:
    <trailertid="1938">This concludes the first chapter, the introduction to the tantra, in the glorious Caamahroaa tantra called <titlexml:lang="en">The Sole Hero</title>.</trailer>
  • Some texts contain appendices. These will be located in the back section of the text. Usually the markup can be applied in the same way as in the main section, however, for Sanskrit Appendices (those that contain a Sanskrit edition of the text)see Appendix B Topics: Appendices--Sanskrit and Other Appendices for some further notes about marking up these sections.
  • As you are working with the TEI texts, you may encounter various problems that require you to search for specific pieces of code or text within the markup. The XQuery/XPath Builder is a useful tool for searching for specific instances of text. See Appendix: XPath/XQuery and Other oXygen Search Tools, for further details on how to use the XQuery/XPath Builder.

Appendix A.5 Edit Milestones

Milestones should be generated automatically by the script before every <p> element and <lg> element; however, we don't use milestones as uniformly as this, and many of the milestones will need to be taken out (For instructions on how to do this see Appendix: Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document). It is important to do an actual visual check of the milestones as they appear in the web display. From the Reading Room, take the perspective of the reader; there should be enough milestones to map out the text, but they should not be distracting to the actual narrative of the text.

Appendix A.6 Check the Alignment for Folio References

Appendix A.6.1 Check Alignment

Web Display:

First, we need to check to make sure the Folio References displayed on the web page are in alignment with the eKangyur. This require some minimal knowledge of Tibetan, so please have another editor check this for you if you don't know how to read Tibetan.

When you check the web display, go to the main translation and click on a folio reference, e.g., "[F.100.a]." This should cause the eKangyur text to pop up. Make sure that the eKangyur page that pops up is the correct page that corresponds to the English translation. You don't need to go through every folio in the text, just check the first two folio refs and the very last one.

Most likely they will already be aligned from the original placeholder data and a correction will not be needed. However, due to a blank page or error in the eKangyur the alignment of the pages might be off by one or more pages. The alignment may be adjusted in the <location>/<volume> element found in the <sourceDesc>; here the start-page and end-page define the span of the folio alignment according to the pages numbers of the eKangyur.

For texts that span two or more volumes, this will be defined by multiple <volume> elements and you should individual check the first and last folio for each volume. Then a <ref type="volume" cRef="V_"/> element needs to be added just before the first folio reference of the new volume. For example, Toh 11 spans two volumes:
<locationcount-pages="788" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="593"number="31" start-page="414"/> <volumeend-page="611"number="32" start-page="2"/> </location>
and it jumps to volume 32 at F.92.b which is marked up as follows in the TEI:
<refcRef="V32"type="volume"/> <refcRef="F.92.b"type="folio"/>
See how this is displayed in Reading Room
* Note, usually the new volume will reset to F.1.b, but Toh 11 is a special case and continues with the numbering "F.92.b" on the first page of volume 32.

Check Folios Utility for Anomalies:

Please also check the Folios Utility from the main Utilities page. The folio utility will show you all the folio references along with their matching correlation in the eKangyur and then flag any anomalies. The anomalies will usually include the following:

  • Occasionally there may be a missing folio reference. It could be that the original translator missed it or due to some formatting the original references were commented out or removed.
  • A folio reference may have been entered incorrectly (e.g. missing a period between the number and letter, "2b").
  • Differences between the spanning pages stated in the header and that found in the eKangyur. Although they are intended to be identical, there may be pagination differences between the Dege print the eKangyur is based on, W4CZ5369, and the official Dege print we use and reference in our <biblScope>, W22084 (Although the eKangyur uses the volume order from W22084).
  • Occasionally there may be anomalies reproduced from the original printed Dege, and certain page numbers may have been skipped or duplicated for various reasons.
  • Occasionally there may be an error in the pagination found in the eKangyur. Use this spreadsheet here if you would like to report them.

Any missing or erroneous folio references will need to be corrected. If it is the eKangyur numbering that is different or in error, there will be a flag on the Folio Utility page and the message, "Logically F.XXX.a/b" appearing next to the reference. You should just make sure that our displayed cRef is the correct one for the official W22084 print and that the English corresponds to the correct page in the eKangyur (whatever its page number might be). When the the eKangyur pagination is different from our official W22084 one, please note this in your list of final issues to be reviewed at the end of markup.

Note, that if the text contains duplicate versions within the Kangyur (such as Toh. 212/520/980), the folio alignment will need to be checked for each version individually.

Appendix A.6.2 Special Cases for Volumes 81 and 83 (only the very last texts), 88, and 100+

***Special Case for Volumes 81, 83, and 88 of the Deg Kangyur/eKangyur*** There is a variation due to the addition of texts in the post par phud printings, which includes our eKangyur in volumes 81, 83 and 88, which are not in the par phud printing such as W22084. In volumes 81 and 83, this only concerns some texts added to the very end of the volume, but for volume 88 the Bodhimaasylakralakadhra (byang chub snying poi rgyan bum gyi gzungs) has the same Tibetan title as Toh 509, but a different Sanskrit title (Toh 509 is Bodhigarbhlakralakadhra). While this is confusing, it is also presumably the reason why the extra text was inserted at this point. If the orginal translator used a par phud printing this then off sets Volume 88 by 17 folios for all texts after Toh. 508. Some points to address that should be addressed:

(1) First be sure that both versions are stated in the <biblscope>. See this example from Toh 526 this is the style that should be used as a template:

<biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 88 (rgyud, na), folios 54.a54.b (in <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings), 71.a71.b (in later printings) </biblScope>

(2) In this situation, because the folio references will not match up with those in the eKangyur, our solution has been to use both folio references. The one that links to the eKanyur will be the default <ref> element and the <ref> that refers to the alternate printing (likely W22084) should have this stated by a work attribute within the <ref> element. See for example from toh. 520:

<refcRef="F.41.a"key="toh520" work="W22084"/> <refcRef="F.58.a"key="toh520"type="folio"/>

Here in the web display both references will be visible but only the one without the "work" attribute will have a clickable link to the eKangyur.

Please add a note after the first folio instance that explains this issue to the reader. If the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need alternate messages, which are applied by using the @key attribute in the <p> elements within the note. The template for the note is as follows:

<noteplace="end"> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 88 TEXT]">Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy in volume 88 (<foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rgyud bum</foreign>, <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">na</foreign>) of the Deg Kangyur between the 1737 <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings. In the latter case, an extra work, <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bodhimaasylakralakadhra</title> (Toh 508, <titlexml:lang="Bo-Ltn">byang chub snying poi rgyan bum gyi gzungs</title>), was added as the second text in the volume, thereby displacing the pagination of all the following texts in the same volume by 17 folios. Since the eKangyur follows the later printing, both references have been provided, with the highlighted one linking to the eKangyur viewer.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT--> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT]">In the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between the 1737 <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings of the Deg Kangyur. Although the discrepancy is irrelevant here, further details concerning this may be found in <reftarget="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix> </ref> of the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

That way the alternate text will display a shorter note that simply references the longer one (For example, see how the note is displayed differently in Toh 212 and Toh 520).

To confirm that the W22084 folio is correct please use the Dege-scan checking script. Note, that BDRC, AIBS, and even the Vienna site are not reliable in terms of distinguishing the "par phud" vs "post par phud" pagination in Vol. 88.

***Special Case for Volume 100, 101, 102, and 103 of the Deg Kangyur*** These volumes are all misplaced by one volume in the eKangyur, so "volume 100" will be "volume 101" in the eKangyur, etc. If this is indeed the case, the adjustment should be made in the <location> found in the <sourceDesc>, however the <biblscope> should not be changed but reflect the correct volume as the text appears in the BDRC. For example, here is the <sourceDesc> for Toh 846a:

<sourceDesc> <biblkey="toh846a"type="text"> <ref>Toh 846a</ref> <biblScope>Deg Kangyur, vol. 100 (gzungs dus, e), folio 3.b.(p.6)</biblScope> <locationcount-pages="1" work="UT4CZ5369"> <volumeend-page="6"number="101" start-page="6"/> </location> <!--...--> </bibl> </sourceDesc>

Additionally, a note about this discrepancy should be placed somewhere in the introduction. As before, if the text includes duplicates at different Toh numbers, then the note will need to include alternate messages applied by using the @key attribute in the <p> elements within the note. The template for this note is as follows:

<noteplace="end"> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 100-103 TEXT]">This text, Toh <fix>###</fix>, and all those contained in this same volume (<foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> <fix>XXXX, X</fix> </foreign>), are listed as being located in volume <fix>###</fix> of the Deg Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databasesincluding the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Roomlist this work as being located in volume <fix>###</fix>. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs dus</foreign> section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Thoku catalog placed another textwhich forms a whole, very large volumethe <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Vimalaprabhnmaklacakratantrak</title> (<titlexml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dus khor grel bshad dri med od</title>, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Deg Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Deg Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar chags</foreign> (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT--> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT">Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for cataloging the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text within vol. <fix>###</fix> or <fix>###</fix> of the Deg Kangyur. See Toh <fix>####</fix>, <reftarget="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix> </ref>, for details.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

See an example how the note is displayed Toh 729 and Toh 1001


Please place the note in the introduction wherever it makes sense, for instance when explaining where the text is found in the Kangyur, and so on. Adapt it to the volume number, e.g., "gzung dus e", or as appropriate if the text appears in two volumes. If needed you can see how it was adapted and placed in the following examples that have already been approved by the editors of the texts: Toh 846, 846a, 847 (145), 848 (522), 980 (212, 520).

Appendix A.7 Transform and Edit the Glossary

Note that there are now two format options available for the Glossary: (1) The Glossary may be entered into an Excel spreadsheet, ".XLSX" file type; or, (2) The glossary may be entered into a table directly into the 84000 Template (that is the main DOCX file).

The latter is preferable to the Excel sheet for three reasons: The latter is preferable to the Excel sheet because Italics may be tagged with the various styles (foreign terms, titles, mantras etc...) from the template, which will then be converted into the proper XML tags by the script; also the spell checkers automatic underlining is available, unlike in Excel; and also one can avoid the general glichiness of working in Excel (apostrophes, unwanted cells going through script, etc...).

The copyeditor will have likely pasted the glossary template directly into the 84000 Template and it should be converted along with the script in which case you can skip the section below and continue on to Appendix A.7.2 Editing the Glossary:. However, if the glossary has come to the markup stage in the form of an Excel spreadsheet, you will need to apply transformation in the section below Appendix A.7.1 "Transform the Glossary from the Spreadsheet."

Appendix A.7.1 Transform the Glossary from the Spreadsheet: (Disregard if the glossary was directly entered into the .docx template)

  • Before transforming the glossary with the script, make sure that the tables are formatted properly. In Excel, there should be three or four sheets labeled "Terms", "People", "Places", and on occasion there will be a fourth sheet that should be labeled "Texts". If the labels of the sheets aren't spelled exactly like this, then the script won't apply the correct type to the <gloss> elements. Each sheet/table needs to have five columns that are to be exactly arranged as follows: (A) Tibetan Wylie, (B) Sanskrit, (C) Translation, (D) Definition, and (E) Alternatives.
  • Note that occasionally you may get a glossary with an additional column of Chinese terms. If this is the case, add Chinese as a sixth column (F). If you need to edit the Chinese from the table side by side with the Tibetan and Sanskrit, that is fine just be sure to move the Chinese column into the sixth place before you convert the file or else the cells will be applied incorrectly by the script.
  • Using a Macro to Correct Initial Apostrophes:
  • When you receive a glossary file in an Excel spreadsheet format, its likely there will be hidden apostrophes in the wylie column. This happens when a straight apostrophe is typed at the beginning of the word, as in the case of an a-chung prefix, "". Excel uses straight apostrophes to override the cell's format when typing numbers so that it considers it as text. In the process it hides this initial apostrophe, although there actually is an apostrophe in the cell, i.e., it disappears unless one actually clicks on the cell and looks in the text box at the top of the screen. In some cases the translator may have entered two apostrophes by mistake, or put one where there shouldn't be one. In all cases, these will need to be corrected, as the translator should not use straight apostrophes in the wylie text at all, but only use left curving apostrophes () (otherwise the script will not display proper Tibetan Unicode below them). Interestingly, the invisible apostrophes are not carried over if you copy a table and paste it into the Glossary Template, However, these initial apostrophes still need to be checked because the author may have thought they had correctly placed one into the beginning of a cell, but then the apostrophe will have disappeared and won't get carried over to the Template. To make this check and fix any errors, you should run the following macro in Excel. This macro will convert each initial straight apostrophe. However, most often these are a spelling error in the wylie transliteration and will need to be corrected (each instance must be verified in a Tibetan dictionary). To make these instances easy to find, the macro also adds 111 so that its easy to make a search for these cells. The 111 is just a marker and will obviously need to be removed too.
  • In case you don't know how to run a macro in Excel, there are many tutorials available on Youtube for both PC and Mac. There might be some differences depending on the version of your Excel software, but they should be pretty straightforward. You may be prevented from running a macro if the file is "shared"; you may have to go to the "Review" tab, click on "Share Workbook," and uncheck the box to share the file with other users (this might be slightly different on Mac). Then you should be able to run the macro without any problem. Here is the macro. Paste the following code into a module window and hit "run":

    Sub AposChange()
    Dim Rng As Range, Cell As Range
    ThisWorkBook.Activate
    Set Rng = Cells.SpecialCells(xlConstants)
    Cells(Rows.Count, Columns.Count).Copy
    For Each Cell In Rng
    If Cell.PrefixCharacter = "'" Then
    Cell.Value = "111 " + Cell.Value
    Cell.PasteSpecial Operation:=xlPasteSpecialOperationAdd
    End If
    Next Cell
    Application.CutCopyMode = False
    End Sub

  • Here is an example. When you look at the spreadsheet you will see:
    khorbajig
    But in the file there is actually a hidden apostrophe:
    'khorbajig
    So after running the macro script it will become:
    111khorbajig
    In this example there should be no hesitation about what to remove, but in other cases you may need to check in the dictionary.
  • Note this macro only runs on one sheet at a time, and it only works on the first sheet in a .xlsx document, so you will need to copy the second and third sheet into new spreadsheet files, open each sheet separately in Excel, and then run the macro separately for each. (Sorry this is such a long process, this is probably a good reason for us to do all the glossaries from an MS Word template in the future.)
  • Transform the Glossary with the XSLT Script:
  • This transformation may be done through the submissions form in the project management app, just the same way you converted the main text, (see instructions again at A.2). Alternatively you may convert the file through oxgarage, (currently this is needed if the .docx from the glossary template is used, although the submissions form will be updated to import this soon). Go to oxgarage at: http://www.tei-c.org/oxgarage/ or its mirror. Select either the option to change a Spreadsheet Microsoft Excel .xlsx (if using spreadsheet), or the option to change a Document Microsoft Word .docx (if using the Template), convert this to TEI P5 XML Document.
  • Download and open the XML in oXygen and use the .xslt stylesheet to transform the XML document. To do this:
    • A. Click on Configure Transformation Scenarios (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon).
    • B. Select New > XML transformation with XSLT.
    • C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop-down menu next to the folder and select Browse Data Source Explorer.
    • D. Select the appropriate script in the apps/84000-import-data/xsl folder: It is the script called "oxGto84000-gloss.xsl" If you get a permissions error email the tech specialist (Dominic) and ask him to give you permissions to open the file.
    • E. For the Transformer confirm that Saxon-PE 9.8.0.12 or the latest "Saxon-" transformer is selected from the drop-down menu.
    • F. Click on the Output tab and check the box that says Open in Editor.
    • G. Click OK, and then select apply associated (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under projects).
  • If you get the script to work, or have someone else convert it for you, you can then paste it into the XML text you are working on. Use another already-published TEI file as a model.
  • The script should be able to convert all three sheets in the combined .xlsx file in one go and create the appropriate type attribute (term, person, or place) if the sheets were labeled properly. However, if one of the sheets isn't converting properly, try breaking the three sheets into three separated .xlsx files and converting each one individually.

Appendix A.7.2 Editing the Glossary:

  • Edit the glossary. Note that when you save the file to the database it will add the xml:id automatically so you dont need to worry about adding these.
