Ostensibly there will be terms in the English prologue/introduction to the appendix that we would won't to link, so these @rend attributes can be applied and adjusted according to the need.

Appendix B.10 Keys: Using the @Key attribute to distinguish the content in duplicate texts with separate Toh numbers

Certain elements allow for the key attribute: <ref>, <p>, <foreign>, and <mantra> elements. These can be used to allow for content to appear in one version of a text but not another. The key corresponds to the key of the specific Toh version of the text, e.g. "toh999", which is defined for each Toh version in the <sourceDesc> However, it is important the we keep the numbered index for all notes and milestones the same throughout all duplicate versions of a text. Therefore the @key attribute is invalid for milestones and notes.

*** Be careful not to add a @key to a <p> that contains a child <note> within it, as that will cause the note to disappear in the other versions and distrupt the index of the notes causing problems for the notes cache.

Here is an overview for how and when to use the key attributes:

  • Inside <ref> elements: This is used to simply provide the alternate folio number, which will link to the proper page of the eKangyur in the reading room. This is very common. E.g., at the beginning of Toh 729:
    <ptid="15"> <refcRef="F.222.a"key="toh729" type="folio"xml:id="UT22084-094-006-20"/> <refcRef="F.160.a"key="toh1001" type="folio"xml:id="UT22084-094-006-21"/> Homage to the Three Jewels! </p>

    Here F.222.a will display in Toh 729 and F.160.a will display in Toh 1001. [See in web display]

  • Inside <p> elements: Principally this is used inside of <note> elements since we do not want to use them on the notes themselves to avoid altering the index. Although we typically don't put <p> elements in <note>s, we can add them in this case in order display a different message depending on the Toh number of the text. The common example of this is for text that are cross listed with the dharani volumes 100-103, which have a discrepancy regarding the volume number found in the Deg, or with the volume 88 texts which have 17 folio number shift between the par phud and post-par phud editions (see Appendix A6). In such cases, a detailed explanation should be given in the relevant version, but a simpler placeholder version that simply references the full note can be used in the other versions (because in order to keep the index number consistent the other versions have to say something). An example of this markup would look like this:
    <noteplace="end" xml:id="UT22084-999-999-999"> <pkey="toh9999A">The folio reference here has a particularity here is a long explanation that is only relevant in this version...</p> <pkey="toh9999B">In the Toh 9999A version of this text the folio references have a particularity; see Toh 9999A, <reftarget="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh9999A.html#end-note-UT22084-999-999-999">note 1</ref> for details.</p> </note>
    Here are is the template to be used for the note in Vol. 88 texts:
    <noteplace="end"> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 88 TEXT]">Two sets of folio references have been included in this translation due to a discrepancy in volume 88 (<foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">rgyud bum</foreign>, <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">na</foreign>) of the Deg Kangyur between the 1737 <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings. In the latter case, an extra work, <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Bodhimaasylakralakadhra</title> (Toh 508, <titlexml:lang="Bo-Ltn">byang chub snying poi rgyan bum gyi gzungs</title>), was added as the second text in the volume, thereby displacing the pagination of all the following texts in the same volume by 17 folios. Since the eKangyur follows the later printing, both references have been provided, with the highlighted one linking to the eKangyur viewer.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT--> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT]">In the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of the text there is a slight discrepancy in the folio numbering between the 1737 <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign> printings and the late (post <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">par phud</foreign>) printings of the Deg Kangyur. Although the discrepancy is irrelevant here, further details concerning this may be found in <reftarget="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix> </ref> of the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

    (See an example in the web display for Toh 212 and Toh 520)

    Here are is the template to be used for the note in Vol. 100-103 texts:
    <noteplace="end"> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR VOL 100-103 TEXT]">This text, Toh <fix>###</fix>, and all those contained in this same volume (<foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn"> <fix>XXXX, X</fix> </foreign>), are listed as being located in volume <fix>###</fix> of the Deg Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databasesincluding the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by the 84000 Reading Roomlist this work as being located in volume <fix>###</fix>. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">gzungs dus</foreign> section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalog, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Thoku catalog placed another textwhich forms a whole, very large volumethe <titlexml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Vimalaprabhnmaklacakratantrak</title> (<titlexml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dus khor grel bshad dri med od</title>, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Deg Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Deg Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur <foreignxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar chags</foreign> (catalog). Please note this discrepancy when using the eKangyur viewer in this translation.</p> <!--THE FOLLOWING ONLY NEEDED FOR TEXTS WITH MULTIPLE TOH VERSIONS OTHERWISE OMIT AND REMOVE THE <p> ELEMENT--> <pkey="[ENTER KEY HERE FOR OTHER TEXT">Note that there is a discrepancy among various databases for cataloging the Toh <fix>###</fix> version of this text within vol. <fix>###</fix> or <fix>###</fix> of the Deg Kangyur. See Toh <fix>####</fix>, <reftarget="https://read.84000.co/translation/toh[ENTER THE TOH NUMBER OF THE VOL 88 VERSION].html#end-note-[ENTER THE XML:ID OF THIS NOTE]">note <fix>#</fix> </ref>, for details.</p> <!--REPLICATE PREVIOUS NOTE IF THERE ARE THREE OR MORE TOH VERSIONS--> </note>

    (See an example in the web display for Toh 729 and Toh 1001)


    In principle this could be used in regular <p> paragraph outside of the notes as well. Although there has yet to be an example of doing this. Just be sure that if this is ever needed, make sure there aren't any <note>s inside the <p> element that has a key.

  • Inside <foreign> or <mantra> elements:

    Typically this is to show alternate versions of dharanis or mantras which often have small alterations in the formulas of the Sanskrit transliteration. Usually these discrepancies are just stated in notes, but in some cases it may be desirable to display the text differently for each version. We have yet to use this technique, but it should be valid in the schema, and if this mode is used in the future an example will be documented here.

Appendix B.11 Chinese and Other Foreign Scripts

Chinese scripts need to always be tagged with a @xml:lang="zh" if they are in Chinese script, e.g. "", and be tagged @xml:lang="Zh-Ltn" if they are in pinyin or other Roman transliteration e.g. "Hny Pnyn". They may be tagged with the @xml:lang attribute either with a <foreign> or <title>, or a <div> element in the case of a Chinese Summary (Chinese summaries should be placed immediately after the English summary in its own separate <div> with an @xml:lang="zh" attribute. It will not be displayed in the English Reading Room but will on the Chinese site). If they are not tagged like this they will not be displayed correctly in a consistent font. The same goes for any Japanese text, which should be tagged "ja" or "Ja-Ltn" in the same manner. There is one exception where we don't need to worry about the tags and that is the Chinese names often found in the <sponsor> element in the TEI header, these aren't displayed anywhere so they do not need the @xml:lang attribute.

Most of us not knowing Chinese and Japanese will sometimes need to guess according to the context whether the script is "zh" or "ja", however, this is not too important because the parser will display Chinese, Japanese, and Korean in the same CJK-pan. So it's not imperative that they are tagged 100% correctly as long as each instance of CJK unicode is tagged with one of the CJK attributes: either "zh" "ja" or "ko".

The following search codes will allow you to easily locate miss-tagged or missing tags:

  • An XPath Query that will locate any CJK unicode character that does not have an ancestor element with @xml:lang="zh" or "ja": //text()[matches(., '&#x4E00;-&#x9FFF;&#x3040;-&#x309F;&#x30A0;-&#x30FF;&#xAC00;-&#xD7AF;')][not(ancestor::*[@xml:lang=('zh') or @xml:lang =('ja') or @xml:lang=('ko')])]
  • An XPath will locate any Roman letter "a-z" or letter "A-Z" that is mislabelled "zh" or "ja": //text()[matches(., '[a-zA-z]')][ancestor::*[@xml:lang = ('zh') or @xml:lang = ('ja')]]
  • Using the regular CTRL-F search in Oxygen you can also locate Chinese script with the regex pattern: \p{script=Han}+
  • And any Japanese script with: [\p{script=Hiragana}\p{script=Katakana}]+
  • Korean: \p{script=Hangul}+

(See more about searching various unicode scripts using regex patterns here)

Keep an eye out for Chinese in the acknowledgements section and the bibliography where titles and names tend to be missed. Note that when a title is given in both Chinese script and pinyin, then two <title> tags are needed to separate the language codes:
<titlexml:lang="Ja-Ltn">Shirukurdo to kindai nihon no kaik: saiiki kodai shiry to nihon kindai bukky</title> <titlexml:lang="ja"></title>
It's not indispensable to check for these every time since we will occasionally run these searches on the full TEI translation folder, but it might be a good idea to run the scripts on text that especially heavy in Chinese references in the notes and bibliography.

Appendix B.12 Cache Files and Re-Caching Publications

Although our TEI files contain complete publications, in order to optimize our reader on the web, a cache for each text is kept in a separate file found in 84000-data/cache. The cache contains data regarding the location of end-notes, milestones, Kangyur folio references, and glossary entries (all of these elements are already in the TEI but the cache tells the parser where to find these elements). A published text will need to be re-cached whenever:

  • A) an endnote, milestone, or Kangyur folio reference has been added or removed.
  • B) If any glossary entries are linked to new locations (locations are determined by milestone placement).

    Glossary entries are cached to improve the web performance. When viewing a text's web display from collaboration in editor mode, you see un-cached glossary instances highlighted in red. These instances will not be linked when the text is pushed to distribution until they are cached

A) Re-caching for changes to endnotes, milestones, or folio refs:

In this first case, the re-cache can simply be done by going to Project Management for the particular text, select "Edit Headers", up the version number and give a note (e.g., "added an endnote") and hit update. It will give you a message "glossary locations may need re-caching" If you made any textual changes you'll need to open the glossary editor and check if any re-caching is needed there, but if you are certain that no textual changes have been made, then this will not be necessary.

Now you can select "Generate new associated files." When you see that the version number of the "CACHE" matches that of the TEI, then you know that the new notes have been cached. The same applies to milestones, and folio references.

B) Re-caching for changes to glossary locations:

In the latter case, the glossary will need to be re-cached from the Glossary Editor. Please refer to Appendix C.4: Caching and Re-caching the Glossary for details. The glossary may be re-cached before or after clicking "Generate new associated files."

Appendix C Guidelines for Glossary

Appendix C.1 Some Notes About How the Glossary Works

Note, also see the Translator Guidelines V.G. Glossary. There is a definitive explanation for translators on how to create their glossaries and these principles should be carried forward in to markup.

How Reader Handles Plurals:

A term will be matched if it is followed by s, es, 's, or s' and then a non-word character, e.g. Maitreya, Maitreya's, Maitreyas. (Unfortunately, the general marker for non-word characters is not Sanskrit-aware. It handles Sanskrit diacritic characters as non-word characters. While we have handled most of the related issues in this case it can result in a few mistakes, e.g. Maitreyasyana).

Capitalization

The glossary is not case-sensitive and will link to names and terms regardless of capitalization. However, note that as a standard within the TEI proper names should be capitalized in the English and Sanskrit field but NOT in the Tibetan Wylie field. Although the parser will display all the English and Sanskrit entries in the Reading Room itself as capitalized regardless of the text found in the TEI.

Use of the <term> Tag to Mark the Same Word Used in Different Ways:

Sometimes we will only want certain instances of a string of text to be marked as a glossary term. For example, perhaps we want the term "appropriate" to be linked to this term when it is used as verb but not when it used as an adjective. The translator guidelines [G4] instructs translators to flag instances of glossary terms that are only relevant to specific passages with the symbol. They are also instructed to specify glossary entries as verbs (vb), nouns (n), or adjectives (adj) in cases where the glossary entry is only intended to link to one form of the word and not others, for example "play" or "appropriate" (These should not be left in the text but replaced with the markup described in the following section). However, many of these may be missed and so all the linked terms should be checked in markup. Note, that we are no longer using zero-width-non-joiners to resolve this issue. Instead, we now use the "mode" attribute within the <gloss> element.

In the glossary, <gloss> nodes can be given the attributes mode="match|marked." Match mode will highlight any matches in the text except where they have been marked up with <term type="ignore">, e.g.:
parse this <termtype="ignore">but not this</term>

*Note that a term in the definition field of a glossary entry linking to itself is ignored automatically.

Marked mode will only match terms that have been marked up with <term> e.g.
Ignore this <term>but match this</term>.
How Tibetan Is Created from Wylie:

Where a glossary item has a Wylie term but no Tibetan the database will auto-generate the Tibetan. To re-create a Tibetan term simply remove the node, save, and refresh. The Wylie string will also have a trailing space enforced. These will produce the respective syllable separators in the Tibetan. Double underscores in Wylie will be replaced with a single space when output to the reader.

If later you make a correction to a Tibetan entry, be sure to delete the term with Tibetan Unicode (the one with xml:lang="bo") this will trigger the database to auto-generate a new one from the corrected Wylie entry, but if you leave it as is the error will remain in the Tibetan Unicode.

Links to Paragraphs with Instances:

The reader lists links to each paragraph that includes instances of a glossary term.

For Multiple Tibetan and Sanskrit Forms of Spelling for a Single Term:

In some cases a single <gloss> entry may have multiple forms for spelling the Tibetan, the Sanskrit, or both. In this case each spelling of the term can be listed separately in its own <term> element. However, Tibetan should be listed first, followed by the Sanskrit, as in the following example for the term "karnikara" (note that a Tibetan "bo" term is auto-generated after each instance of Tibetan Wylie "Bo-Ltn"):

<glosstype="term" xml:id="UT22084-055-001-5217"> <term>karnikara</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">kar ni </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dong ka </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">dkar ni </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">karikra</term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">mucilinda</term> <termtype="definition">Pterospermum acerifolium. Other names include bayur, muchakunda, muchalinda, and dinner-plate tree.</term> </gloss>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

Note that in the example above, these spelling variations are supplied by the author but don't actually appear in the translated text. If there are alternative spellings of a term within the text itself, they need to be marked as type="alternative."

Use of Alternatives in the Glossary Entry:

Glossary items can also include <term type="alternative"> nodes to specify other variations in the spelling that should be marked in the text:

<glosstype="term" xml:id="UT22084-060-005-541"> <term>door of the Dharma</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">chos kyi sgo </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">dharmamukha</term> <termtype="definition">See Dharma-door.</term> <termtype="alternative">doors of the Dharma</term> </gloss>

(See in the Reading Room; note that the alternative term isn't listed in the glossary but is linked in the text as the third occurrence).

Alternatives may be added for any related terms that should be linked to the entry such as:

  • When a plural "-s" appears in the middle of the string in certain cases and is not linking (as in the XML example above), or not linking because the plural has an irregular spelling, e.g. "phenomena" and "phenomenon"; "birth-story" and "birth-stories"; etc...
  • Alternate nominal or verbal uses of the same term: appropriate, appropriated, appropriation.
  • Extended names such as "Majur" and "Majur the crown prince". In this last case only if the simple name is clearly represented in the extended one, otherwise a second <gloss> should be added referring to the primary one, e.g.: The Great Compassionate One -- See Avalokitevara.

However, alternatives should not be used for two semantically different English words, even if they are translated from the same Tibetan term and have similar meaning. For example if "offering" and "worship" are both used for "mchod pa / pj". They should be given two different glossary entries.

The 84000 translator's guidelines (G4) states this clearly:

If the same Tibetan or Sanskrit word was translated in more than one way, include an entry for each, and place in the definition a reference to the other rendering, e.g. for the entry Offering (mchod pa / pj): Also translated here as worship, (and vice versa for the entry Worship).

There are two reasons for this. (1) We don't want readers unfamiliar with Tibetan and Sanskrit clicking on a term like "worship" and having it link to "offering," and (2) Some readers may be reading the text in a PDF format or even someday in print and will need to look up terms alphabetically as the hyperlinks won't be available.

Some of these alternatives may have been entered improperly and will need to be separated into separate entries. This should be handled by copy editors, but in some cases it may be missed and markup editors will be more capable of spotting inconsistencies or issues in the glossary since they will be able to actually click on the links and check them in the Reading Room.

There has been some further discussion regarding whether alternatives should be used when the English words for a glossary entry are used in a different word order. So in the example above for "door of the dharma" one might ask, should this itself be used as an alternative linking to the entry for "dharma-door" or should it be in a separate entry? In this case it isn't such an issue that the reader would click on "door of the Dharma" and see the entry for "Dharma-door" but it is an issue for anyone reading the PDF. However it is quite sensible that the reader would simply search for the term under "dharma" if they did not find it in "door". If there are a just a few instances of these it makes sense to create separate entries, but if the amount of entries with alternate word order is becoming extensive then this could be an issue because it will muddy up the glossary, be difficult for reader to find all the instances of a term from the "passages contain this term" field, and also it could muddy up the cumulative glossary. When there are a lot of such alternatives it may be better to set such phrases as "door of the dharma" as an alternative provided that it would be sensible from the perspective of the reader and there aren't semantically distinct words (e.g., you wouldn't want to add "gateway of the dharma" as an alternative). If there are a lot of such instances, you should also check with the editors about changing the translation to be more consistent (make notes about such instances in the Reading Room Worksheet). This should be taken on a case by case basis and always thought of from the readers perspective.

Further Explanation on the Mode Attribute:

The mode attribute is not required, but when present it can either be "match" or "marked." "Match" is the default (where this attribute is not specified). "Match" will behave in the normal way: the text is scanned for glossary matches and highlighted accordingly.

"Marked," on the other hand, will only consider text strings that have been marked up with <term>. An example for "appropriate" is below:

<!-- Glossary item with mode "marked" --> <item> <glossmode="marked"type="term" xml:id="UT22084-044-003-185"> <term>appropriate</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">len pa </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">dna</term> <termtype="definition">See appropriation.</term> <termtype="alternative">appropriated</term> </gloss> </item>
<!-- Only marked up instances in the text will be highlighted --> <ptid="38"> Bhadrapla said, Blessed One, sentient beings in this world do not know about their consciousness. If not understanding consciousness is akin to not knowing of a jewel hidden in a box, what then, Blessed One, is consciousness? Why is it called consciousness? Blessed One, a dying persons limbs and eyes fail; when, at the moment of death, his faculties cease and he loses his constituent elements, how does this consciousness undergo transfer from the body, and what type of form does it have? What is its nature? How does it separate from the body? How does consciousness, after abandoning one body, <term>appropriate</term> another body? After abandoning the elements and casting off the sensory fields, how does it leave this world and go on to the next? How does it <term>appropriate</term> different bodies? Blessed One, how do a dying persons sensory fields follow him? Blessed One, how does someone experience, in another world, the roots of virtue accumulated in this world? How is it that the roots of virtue accumulated by the current aggregates are experienced later on by another set of aggregates? How does consciousness follow the body? How do the sensory fields follow the body? </p>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

Linking <term>s in the body of the text to the glossary entry directly with the @ref attribute.

Sometimes, if there are three or more glossary entries with the same exact string, the marked application alone will not be sufficient. In this case the duplicate <gloss> entries should all be tagged mode="marked" and the terms within the body of the text may be linked directly to the proper glossary entry by adding a @ref attribute that points that term to the specific entry attributed to it. For example there are three separate entries for the name "Upananda" in Toh 340. These may be distinguished in the text as follows:

<ptid="2067">He had come to rvast very late, <refcRef="F.184.a"type="folio"/> and seeing that the other monks had already gone carrying their alms bowls filled, he thought, I will ask where I should go to quickly get some alms. So he went to see Upananda and asked him, <!--...--> </p> <!--...--> <ptid="4741">King Prasenajit implored the Blessed One, Lord, the Blessed One has tamed vicious ngas like <term>Nanda</term>, <termref="UT22084-073-001-5716">Upananda</term>, <!--...--> </p> <!--...--> <ptid="3024">Now the king had two wise chief ministers, capable, clear-minded, <refcRef="F.274.a"type="folio"/> trustworthy, shrewd, disciplined, and prudent. Their names were <termref="UT22084-073-001-5432">Nanda</term> and <term>Upananda</term>.</p> <!--...--> <!--...IN THE GLOSSARY ENTRIES:...--> <item> <glosstype="person" xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5519"> <term>Upananda (the monk)</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga bo </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">Upananda</term> <termtype="definition">A member of the kya clan and monk of the Buddhas order, he often appears in the vinaya texts, as here, to exemplify certain wrong behaviors. </term> <termtype="definition">Not to be confused with <term>Upananda</term>, one of King Mahdeva's ministers; or with <termref="UT22084-073-001-5716">Upananda</term>, the nga.</term> <termtype="alternative">Upananda</term> </gloss> </item> <item> <glossmode="marked"type="person" xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5520"> <term>Upananda (the minister)</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga bo </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">*Upananda</term> <termtype="definition">Along with Nanda, one of King Mahadevas two chief ministers in the city of Mithil.</term> <termtype="alternative">Upananda</term> </gloss> </item> <item> <glossmode="marked"type="person" xml:id="UT22084-073-001-5716"> <term>Upananda (the nga)</term> <termxml:lang="Bo-Ltn">nye dga bo </term> <termxml:lang="bo"></term> <termxml:lang="Sa-Ltn">*Upananda</term> <termtype="definition">The name of a certain nga. </term> <termtype="definition">Not to be confused with <term>Upananda</term>, one of King Mahdeva's ministers; or with Upananda, the monk.</term> <termtype="alternative">Upananda</term> </gloss> </item>

See this example in Reading Room.

***Important Note: if you use a @ref to mark a terms to a glossary entry with mode="marked", be sure to also add @refs to any terms that need to be linked to the other mode="marked" entry(s) otherwise the parser may link all marked terms without @refs to the first mode="marked" entry. So as in the example above, instances of both Upananda the minister and nga need to be marked with <term> elements with @refs, but Upananda the monk may be left as is because the first entry isn't mode="marked"

Blocking the glossary from linking to entire paragraphs, stanzas, divisions, or mantras

Optionally an @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute may be added to any <p>, <lg>, <div>, or <mantra> element to block all the text within from linking to the glossary. Typically we want to do this for Sanskrit appendices, long Sanskrit quotes, or mantras where the complex Sanskrit spelling declinations will cause terms to be linked inconsistently. Note, the @rend="ignoreGlossary" attribute can ostensibly be used on any element in the TEI document although the schema may need to be updated to validate it in particular cases. Email the ODD editor (Celso) if the schema needs to be updated.

Some Final Tips for Polishing the Glossary:
  • Sometimes a term will appear in its own definition. By default the parser will block these from linking to themselves.
  • If there are references in the definition to a term, such as "see also...", they can be placed into a second <term type="definition"> line, to create some visual lightness in the final webdisplay.
  • If a word is not linking in the webdisplay, here are some common causes for instances not being detected by the parser:
    • Plurals in the middle of strings of words (where the "s" doesn't come at the end).
    • An extra space at the end of the term in the glossary.
    • Sanskrit soft-hypens in the term not matching with the glossary entry.
  • Occasionally you will see a word in the text that is similar to a glossary term but isn't linked because it takes as different form. For instance, "appropriate" is in the glossary, but you see "appropriation" in the text. If you see instances like this you can add an <term type="alternative"> to that <gloss> item, but be sure that you are not then linking to other unwanted instances as well.

Appendix C.2 Applying Type Attributes for the Sanskrit Term

Sometimes there are variables in regard to the source of the Sanskrit terms that are listed in the glossary. For example, translators are instructed in the guidelines to apply asterisks * in the Sanskrit field for terms that are reconstructions and not attested elsewhere. In such a case, the asterisk should be removed and instead one of the "...Reconstruction" @type attributes should be applied instead. This will signal the parser to display an asterisk in the reading room, but it will prevent the asterisk from muddying up our TEI data. We use the following type attributes to distinguish these variables:

  • @type="semanticReconstruction"

    This Sanskrit term is not attested but was reconstructed semantically. That is to say the Tibetan was back translated into Sanskrit, for instance providing the Skt. "Pramodyakrti" for the name of the buddha "mchog dga'i grags pa" found in the Tibetan.

  • @type="transliterationReconstruction"

    This Sanskrit term is not attested but was reconstructed according to the Tibetan transliteration. This is only used when the source Tibetan is a transliteration of the Sanskrit. For instance providing the Skt. "Yagarvat" for the name "yang gar ba ti" found in the Tibetan. Often there are errors in the Tibetan transliteration which may be emended in the Skt. field.

  • @type="sourceAttested"

    The Sanskrit is specifically attested in the Sanskrit version of this text, and this is the source of the Sanskrit field for this glossary entry. If there is a case in which there is both a generic Sanskrit attested in other sources and a unique attestation in the specific Sanskrit version of this text, two Sanskrit fields may be added to the entry (one with @type="sourceAttested" and the other without a @type attribute). ***(1/7/2022) Note, this is a new application to the markup and has not been applied yet to previous texts. There maybe further discussion at some point regarding how to process this attribute.

  • Note there are currently some other @type values allowed in the schema for <term> including "person-interlocutor" "person-main-speaker" "person-topical" "main-subject" "secondary-subject" These are in regards to the metadata in the <teiHeader> and should not be used in the glossary. Please disregard these (they are currently not being implemented in the teiHeader either -1/7/2022).

Appendix C.3 Editing Shared Entities

Because the shared-entities are a new feature of our developing cumulative glossary. The guidelines have been moved to this google doc so that details regarding bugs, issues, and resolving ambiguities may be collaboratively discussed and commented upon. At some point when the guidelines are well defined, the guidelines will be added here.

Appendix C.4 Caching and Re-caching the Glossary

Note that the glossary needs to be specifically re-cached from the Glossary Editor, while when endnotes, milestones, or folio references should be re-cached from project management (see Appendix B TOPICS: Cache Files and Re-Caching Publications).

To re-cached from the Glossary Editor: Click on "Batch update options" and selecting "Re-cache location of all entries". This will re-cache the glossary according to the current matching and modes.

Some large texts, particularly ones with extensive glossaries may take a long time to re-cache (the longest example of this is Toh 94 which currently takes about 6 hours), however most of texts should only take a few seconds. Note that the time it took previously to re-cache will be displayed by the editor.

This re-cache function runs in the background, so you can work on other things or open other texts in the editor while it is running. It will continue to display the message "job running, please wait" until the re-cache is complete. (to check if it is done, run a new search, refreshing the page doesn't always work in this case).

After re-caching the glossary editor will tell you:

  • How many entries are cached behind the current version. It will display this in the header e.g. "63 Behind". This is the number of entries that were cached in the previous cache file. This can be searched as "Cached behind".
  • How many entries have newly cached locations. This will display in the header e.g. "3 new". This is the number of entries with newly cached locations. This should be double checked to make sure they were intended to be cached. If they look fine, then no further actions are needed, however if there are some that shouldn't be cached, please correct them in the TEI and re-cache again.
  • Any missing entries will be flagged as "missing". These locations have been lost for some reason and should be investigated/corrected in the TEI.

If it is a large text and it will take an long time to re-cache, it is suitable to just cache glossary entries individually if you're certain that only a few glossary entries have changed. For example if you needed to add one glossary entry, "nga" to Toh 94, instead of doing a full recache, you could instead add the entry, then search in the glossary editor for the entry "nga" and click "cache locations". Then you would update the file version say from v1.0.1 to v1.0.2, but leave the cache as v1.0.1, then when you push the TEI for v1.0.2 it will properly link to the locations of the instance "nga" because those locations have been added to v1.0.1 when you clicked "cache locations" of "nga". Thus you have avoided the 6 hours wait and CPU usage to cache just one entry.


return to table of contents

Appendix D Guidelines for Entering Milestones into the TEI Document

Milestones are applied to the document with the <milestone unit="chunk"/> tag. Because the 84000 reading room does not have page numbers, milestones are particularly important for referencing sections or paragraphs in the text.

Milestones should be applied to the text at places where there is a logical/thematic division in the text. Sometimes, milestones can be placed at the beginning of each paragraph of prose. In cases where paragraphs are very short (only one or two sentences) milestones can be placed one for every two or more paragraphs depending on the context, or a particularly short paragraph can share the milestone with that of a larger previous or later paragraph that shares the same theme.

To a large degree the editor should use their own judgment: If the milestones are too frequent, then it will become distracting to the reader on the page. If they are too far apart, it will be difficult to cite particular passages of the text. It is helpful to check the display in the reading room after applying milestones to make sure they appear in a convenient way and to visually check there is general consistency throughout the text.

Often there will be very short paragraphs used during sections of dialogue. A logical way to organize these sections is to allow one question and answer to be given a single milestone. For example, the following passage could be given one milestone:

<milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p>The Lord then said to the venerable riputra, riputra, did you see that universe Abhirati, and the Tathgata Akobhya?</p> <p>riputra replied, I saw it, Lord! May all living beings come to live in a buddhafield as splendid as that! May all living beings come to have miraculous powers just like those of the noble Licchavi Vimalakrti!</p>

(See how this example is rendered in the Reading Room).

If either the question or the answer are very short paragraphs (one or two sentences), then they could be appended to the milestone along with their respective question and answer. However, if both the question and answer are long paragraphs in themselves, they should each be given their own milestone. Of course, there will always be unique situations such as questions being answered with another question and so forth. The editor should in general use their own discretion to decide what frequency of milestones would be the most useful and least distracting to the reader. They should to try to be consistent with their usage.

When entering milestones for lines of verse, the editor should apply milestones in a consistent manner, which will typically be one milestone marker between every line group element <lg>. Usually this will be a verse of four lines in English.

For example, see how milestones are applied to the following verses from The Teachings of Vimalakrti:

<milestoneunit="chunk"/> <lg> <l>Pure are your eyes, broad and beautiful, like the petals of a blue lotus.</l> <l>Pure is your thought, having discovered the supreme transcendence of all trances.</l> <l>Immeasurable is the ocean of your virtues, the accumulation of your good deeds.</l> <l>You affirm the path of peace. O Great Ascetic, obeisance to you!</l> </lg> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <lg> <l>Leader, bull of men, we behold the revelation of your miracle.</l> <l>The superb and radiant fields of the sugatas appear before us,</l> <l>And your extensive spiritual teachings, that lead to immortality </l> <l>Make themselves heard throughout the whole reach of space.</l> </lg> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <lg> <l>Dharma-King, you rule with the Dharma your supreme Dharma-kingdom,</l> <l>And thereby bestow the treasures of the Dharma upon all living beings.</l> <l>Expert in the deep analysis of things, you teach their ultimate meaning.</l> <l>Sovereign Lord of Dharma, obeisance to you!</l> </lg>

(See example in reading room.)

One exception to this may occur when a set of verses are introduced by a very short line, such as The Blessed One said: In this case use your judgment to place a milestone either before this short line and not the verse, or vice-versa, depending on the spatial and thematic context you are working in:

<milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-055-005-264"/> <ptid="250">When the Blessed One had explained the meaning to them, he spoke these verses:</p> <lgtid="251"> <l>Some say that what is created is compounded,</l> <l>While others say that it is uncompounded.</l> <l>However, as both apprehend phenomena, both are concepts.</l> <l>Such conceptual elaborations are called impure.</l> </lg> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-055-005-266"/> <lgtid="252"> <l>Phenomena are not created by anyone, nor does anything destroy them.</l> <l>No one sees them, knows them, or is close to them.</l> <l>Such untenable domains of imputed thought</l> <l>All are designated empty.</l> </lg>

(See example in reading room.)

In another case the editor may encounter short sentences used in a debate-like dialogue. For example, in this following dialogue found in The Teachings of Vimalakrti:

<milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p>Majur: What is the great compassion of a bodhisattva ?</p> <p>Vimalakrti: It is the giving of all accumulated roots of virtue to all living beings.</p> <p>Majur: What is the great joy of the bodhisattva?</p> <p>Vimalakrti: It is to be joyful and without regret in giving.</p> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p>Majur: What is the equanimity of the bodhisattva? </p> <p>Vimalakrti: It is what benefits both self and others.</p> <p>Majur: To what should one resort when terrified by fear of life?</p> <p>Vimalakrti: Majur, a bodhisattva who is terrified by fear of life should resort to the magnanimity of the Buddha.</p>

(See example in reading room.)

A similar passage in The Absorption of the Thus-Gone Ones Wisdom Seal:

<milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-055-005-220"/> <ptid="206">Blessed One, to what do the terms <distinct>unchanging</distinct> and <distinct>nonconceptual</distinct> refer?</p> <ptid="207">Noble sons, <distinct>unchanging</distinct> and <distinct>nonconceptual</distinct> refer to <distinct>nonreferential</distinct>.</p> <ptid="208">Blessed One, to what does <distinct>nonreferential</distinct> refer?</p> <ptid="209">Noble sons, <distinct>nonreferential</distinct> refers to <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct>.</p> <milestoneunit="chunk" xml:id="UT22084-055-005-224"/> <ptid="210">Blessed One, to what does <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct> refer?</p> <ptid="211">Noble sons, <distinct>inexhaustible</distinct> refers to <distinct>unborn</distinct>.</p> <ptid="212">Blessed One, to what does <distinct>unborn</distinct> refer?</p> <ptid="213">Noble sons, <distinct>unborn</distinct> refers to <distinct>uninterrupted</distinct>.</p>

(See example in reading room.)

<milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p>A bodhisattvas buddhafield is a field of virtuous application. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who live by all virtuous principles will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>A bodhisattvas buddhafield is the magnificence of the conception of the spirit of enlightenment. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who are actually participating in the Mahyna will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <milestoneunit="chunk"/> <p>A bodhisattvas buddhafield is a field of generosity. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who give away all their possessions will be born in his buddhafield.</p> <p>A bodhisattvas buddhafield is a field of morality. When he attains enlightenment, living beings who follow the path of the ten virtues with positive thoughts will be born in his buddhafield.</p>

(See example in reading room.)

Here the editor might place a milestone for each item in the list depending on the length of each paragraph. It might also be appropriate to place the milestones according to logical groupings in the list, for example place one milestone for the four immeasurables, one milestone for the six paramitas, etc. Finally, if the list becomes overburdened by milestones, the editor can add the milestones for every two or four items in the list. In this case it might be worthwhile to check how many items there are in the list then seek a reasonable way to divide it up evenly.

If the editor is not sure about the frequency for applying milestones, he or she can refer to some of the other texts in the reader and see how frequently the milestones are used in other texts. For now, Toh 131 is a good example.

While editing in oXygen, it can be easier to edit milestones while in "author mode" (go to "Author" in the menu bar and click on "Switch to Author Mode." This will show the layout of the text more clearly and you can remove the milestones by double clicking on them and hitting delete.) This is a useful way to quickly edit milestones, but should not be a substitute for checking visually in the Reading Room.

There are a few places where we always want to have a milestone: (1) trailers (both at the end of chapters and any concluding trailer to the entire text); (2) the opening homage and the following paragraph; and (3) in ancillary sections (summary, acknowledgement, colophon, etc.).

return to table of contents

Appendix E Guidelines for Entering Soft Hyphens to Sanskrit

Note that only editors with a basic understanding of the spelling and sandhi rules of Sanskrit should proceed with this step. You don't need to be an expert in Sanskrit, as most words can be looked up in online references, however, for this step editors will need to have a clear grasp on how the sandhi rules in Sanskrit work. If not please request that another editor with this skill to complete this task.

  • Look for long Sanskrit chains, and add optional soft-hyphens at points where there are chains that are 15+ characters long. Optional soft-hyphens are created with the character code:
    &#173;
    Note that after you save the XML these will look like regular hyphens, but if you move the blinking cursor to the space just before the hyphen you will notice there is a different character code displayed at the bottom of the oXygen screen.
  • The long Sanskrit chains can be found easily by going to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder, then in the XPath/XQuery Builder window type the following code and press the red play button://*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn'] You can save this query for later by clicking on the star and choosing "add to favourites."
  • Note that texts that have Sanskrit appendixes will not be checked by the code above because these sections aren't marked with an @xml:lang attribute. Generally, the Sanskrit appendixes such as the one in Toh 437 does not need soft hyphens because it is not anticipated that they will be read on small devices. However, occasionally there may be extremely long strings in the appendices that will fill the screen even on a regular web browser. For the appendices our current limit is any strings longer than 40 continuous characters without as space. To search the appendices, press CTRL/SHIFT/H to "search in files" then check the "regular expression" box, in the scope select "All open files", and in "Restrict to XPath:" enter the code: //text(). Finally, in the search field enter the following regex code: (^|\s|-)[^\s-]{40,}($|\s|-). This should give you a list of all the 40+ strings while ignoring tags, spaces, or hyphens.
  • Be careful when adding the soft hyphens as they should only be placed at certain points in the words where they do not interfere with the Sanskrit rules of sandhi. When adding the soft hyphens please follow the following guidelines:
  • Guidelines for Adding Soft-Hyphens to Sanskrit:

    • 1. As we are not using full justification anyway, (a) most Sanskrit words dont need hyphenation unless they are longer than 5 or 6 syllables, but (b) may be necessary for shorter words especially in text titles on the title page. I therefore tend to place soft hyphens in all of the text titles, in verse passages, in the bibliography entries, and in notes and glossary entries (which require shorter lines in general).

    • 2. Place a soft hyphen (a) only between the words of a compound; (b) even then only when there are no changes brought about by sandhi (because putting a hyphen would logically mean undoing the sandhi, and the hyphens were talking about may or may not appear); and (c) avoiding confusing remnants.

      A couple of examples:

      Ratnagotravibhgottaratantrastra would be Ratna-gotra-vibhgottara-tantra-stra. If we divided the 5-syllable sequence in the middle, that would have to undo the sandhi and become -vibhga-uttara-, which only works in the presence of a hard hyphen. Theoretically we could put a hyphen at vi-bhga, but that would risk leaving us with -gotravi-, which would be potentially confusing to read.

      The maximum we could hyphenate antnantaivsanbhisadhisamuccedaka would be antnanta-i-vsanbhi-sadhi-sam-ucchedaka, because antnanta and vsanbhi-sadhi would become anta-ananta and vsana-abhi-sadhi. In a case like that, I would also prefer to avoid ending up with antnantaivsanbhi-sadhisamuccedaka, because the abhi- really belongs with the sadhi; its a possible break but is confusing to read.

    • One resource that is helpful for determining the breaks in Sanskrit chains in the online Cologne Sanskrit Dictionary. This one is really helpful because it has a drop down menu of similarly spelled words when you hit the enter key, however, I think this only works when you use the Kyoto-Harvard Transliteration scheme "KH." You might try the other ones but I found that this is the only one that gave the drop down list for me. Then when you find a big word in the dictionary in the definition entry you will see * whenever there is sandhi, though this isn't 100% reliable. Sometimes it is missing for some reason, so be careful if the spelling looks weird.
    • In certain cases there may be long 15+ Sanskrit chains that cannot be broken due to the sandhi, or long Sanskrit compounds whose pieces cannot be easily determined with online resources. If this is the case make a list of problematic instances to note for the leading editors, and also check these instances to see if the pose any major difficultly for the web display. These instances are rare, but they do come up now and then.
    • It is acceptable to add an optional hyphen at the end of "mah-" as in "mah-yna" even though technically the long would be lost, as this is a well known word and unlikely to be misread.
    • Note that when you add the optional hyphens to a glossary item where the translation uses the Sanskrit (This will mainly be in the Persons and Places section of the glossary) the hyphens will have to match all those instances within the body of the text or they will not link to the glossary term, so it is best to start from the glossary and work your way backwards. For all of these person and place terms do a search and replace so that the hyphens match in all the instances of that term (be cautious when doing large search-and-replaces that you dont make any unintended changes).

return to table of contents

return to checklist for 84000 TEI markup editors step 8

Appendix F Miscellaneous Troubleshooting

Appendix F.1 Text Mysteriously Appearing in TEI from Hidden Text in the MS Word Document

Occasionally you may see a string of gibberish mysteriously appears in the middle of the TEI file. This issue occurs when a string is applied as "hidden" through the Font menu in MS Word (Right-Click -> Font -> then check "Hidden"). The problem is that our TEI conversion scripts makes the string of text reappear when it is converted from DOCX to TEI. This reappearance is implemented in the initial OxGarage script, so I am unable to remedy it with our own XSLT script.

A segment of Hiddentext could be inadvertently contained inside a DOCX submitted for publication, it's very rare since it seems like one would need to do it intentionally, but it could possibly occur when a .DOCX file is edited from an alternate word processor in the translation process (this is just my theory). Since it is hidden in the document it goes unnoticed in our own copyediting phase, but reappears in the TEI.

However, there is an easy way to check if a text has Hidden text:

  • (1) On Windows, right click the DOCX file -> rename the file, and change the file type from .docx to .zip. It will give you a warning, but just hit okay.
  • (2) Then extract that .zip file with an archive extractor like WinZip, 7Zip, or whatever.
  • (3) Then use a texteditor like Notepad++ or Oxygen that has a Searchfolder application and search the extracted archive for the tag: w:vanish Any instance of the tag will show you "hidden" text which will appear in the TEI after the conversion; you should then evaluate whether those specific strings were intended to be in the text but were accidentally removed, or if they are remnant edits that shouldn't be there.

An example can be found as follows: go to Project Management and download the last .docx for Toh 257 "toh-257-quintessence-of-the-sun-for-markup-apr-18-2022.docx", performing the search method above will reveal a "<w:vanish>But h<w:vanish/>" tag). In this instance it was a remnant edit that seemed to be preserved from an earlier time (this led me to believe that some of these are saves from alternate word processors).

This situation is pretty rare, so it's probably not necessary to check every time. But, do check if (A) you notice odd strings showing up in the middle of your markup, or (B) this check should be performed for any large complex text, especially if it was passed around a lot between different parties.

Appendix G GitHub

84000 GitHub
This is a link to the 84000 GitHub. This is where all our TEI files may be accessed, and any of our data related resources are publicly available for access and discussion.

return to table of contents

Appendix H Guidefor Using an XSLT Conversion Script

This is the method that bypasses the process of running the .docx through Project Management.

If you need to convert a word .docx created from our template into TEI you will need to first run the file through the oXgarage website or it's mirror site. Convert the file to a "TEI P5 XML Document" and then run our own .xslt script on the document.

Here are instructions for using an XSLT script in oXygen:

  • A. Click on Configure Transformation Scenarios (it should be a wrench with a red arrow on the oXygen ribbon).
  • B. Select New > XML transformation with XSLT.
  • C. For the XSL URL: click on the drop down menu next to the folder and select Browse Data Source Explorer.
  • D. Select the appropriate .xsl document from the database. For example the script for transforming a .docx created from the 84000 template can be found in: 84000 Collaboration > apps > import-84000-data > xsl > oxGto84000.xsl.
  • E. Click on the Output tab and check the box that says Open in Editor.
  • F. Click okay, and then select apply associated (the transformation scenario you just made should be ticked under projects).

Appendix I Guide and Checklist for Updating the Schema and ODD

Note that updating the schema and ODD is a bit more complicated, so this should be handled by the lead editors or technicians. Otherwise, if you are working on a markup and notice that the schema needs to be updated (i.e., there is some markup needed but you are getting a schema error for that markup), then make this a point to send to the lead editors in your final list of questions and issues for finalizing the text. Please disregard the following instructions unless you are a lead editor or technician.

  • This appendix gives a brief explanation and checklist for how to update the ODD. However, you may need to refer to the 22nd chapter of the TEI guidelines for a more detailed explanation on how the elements in the ODD work. You may also need to refer to the 23rd chapter of the TEI guidelines which contains information on the content models, attribute customizations, and TEI conformance.
  • Most of the restrictions in the ODD are defined in the element specifications. In order to create documentation, an <elementSpec> has been created for all of the elements we use. There are also some schema restrictions defined in class specifications, <classSpec>, and macro specifications, <macroSpec>. In our ODD's XML the <classSpec>s are listed first followed by the <macroSpec>s followed by the <elementSpec>s all in alphabetical order. If you need to jump to a specific element, they can easily be found by searching for their ident attribute. For example, to find the <elementSpec> for the "front", search for
    cident="front"
    and this will take you to that section of the ODD.
  • Adding new elements will require creating a new <elementSpec> and adding it to the ODD. Adding or modifying attributes can be done in that specific element's <attList>. For example here is the <attList> for the <title> element:
    <attList> <attDefident="type"mode="change"> <desc>classifies the title according to the TBRC typology.</desc> <desc>classifies the title according to the 84000 typology.</desc> <valListmode="replace"type="closed"> <valItemident="mainTitle"/> <valItemident="longTitle"/> <valItemident="otherTitle"/> </valList> </attDef> <attDefident="xml:id"mode="delete"/> <attDefident="level"mode="delete"/> <attDefident="xml:lang"mode="change" usage="req"/> </attList>
    The <attDef> defines a particular attribute for <title>, along with a description <desc>. The <valList> defines what values are allowed in the "type" attribute. Since we don't use the default "xml:id" and "level" attributes in our <title>s they have been set to "delete" so they won't appear in our documentation. We want the "xml:lang" to be required for all <title>s so the usage has been set to "reg". More details should can be found in the TEI guidelines.
  • When a language needs to be added to the schema, the language list is actually found in the class specification for "att.global" that defines the "xml:lang" attribute. It should be added here so it will apply to all the elements that use "xml:lang". To find this section search for
    attDefident="xml:lang"
  • Content Models: The structure for the schema--i.e., what elements are allowed to be nested in what elements--are contained in the ODD content models, <content>. Each element used in our TEI has a content model defined in its element specification, or if it isn't stated then the default TEI content model will be used when the schema is generated in from Oxgarage. You can look up the default content model in the appendix of the TEI Guidelines Because the 84000 schema is very restrictive, we use often directly use relax ng code within the ODD to define content models for the structure of the text. That is why you will see the prefix "rng:-" before many of the elements there. When the content model needs to be updated, that is the rules which govern how the elements are to be nested, look for the <content> element in the ODD for that element's <elementSpec>. If is a global rule for that element it will be found there. However, keep in mind if it is a rule specific to the order or structure found in the <front>, <body>, or <back>, then the content model will be found in those element's content models.
  • To avoid writing repetitive code, there are also some content models declared in the <marcroSpec> these may be referred to in other content models, which will look something like this:
    <rng:refname="paragraph"/>
    In this example the rng element points to the content model of our basic paragraph. And if that needs to be updated in can be done so in the <macroSpec> for "paragraph".
  • Note there are also many descriptions, <desc>, as well as examples <egXML> contained in all the specifications. It is not required to update these for the generation of the schema, but when you make in update, it would be good to update these as well so that our documentation can be most up to date. Also consider whether an update is something that the markup editors need to be aware of during their work flow. If it is, please add some explanation and/or protocol for the markup editors in the "Checklist for 84000 TEI Markup Editors". This appendix is found in the <back> of the ODD.
  • Occasionally, we may add a new element to our schema that is already included in one of the standard TEI modules. Note, that these standard elements are all declared at the beginning of the ODD in the <moduleRef>. This happened to me, I couldn't figure out why the <hi> element wasn't validating even though it was declared in an <elementSpec>. The reason was I had assumed it was declared as a part of the "core" module, but had forgotten to add it to the list within the <moduleRef>.
  • If you can't figure out why an added element or attribute isn't validating properly for a schema update. A good technique is to paste that element into a TEI document apply the schema, and read the schema error message at the bottom of the oXygen window. It should tell you what the schema is expecting and based on that you can determine where and which content model needs to be updated. Also keep in mind that any element from the standard TEI modules will have the default content model if a new one isn't declared, so you may need to look up the element in the TEI guidelines to find its default content model as well as its other parameters.
  • To summarize here is a brief checklist for any updates for the ODD/schema.
    • 1) Make any changes to the element that needs update in that elements <elementSpec>
    • 2) Does this change need to be reflected in the content model? If so make the appropriate corrections to the <content> found within the <elementSpec>s for the <teiHeader>, <front>, <body>, <back>, or possibly one of the <macroSpec>s
    • 3) Update examples, <egXML> and/or descriptions <desc> if needed.
    • 4) Update the markup editor's checklist if needed.

Appendix J XPath/XQuery and Other oXygen Search Tools

  • Further Useful Tips for using the XPath/XQuery Builder
    • The Xpath/XQuery builder is a useful tool for searching for unwanted stuff in the glossaries like brackets, slashes and so on. To open, go to Window > Show View > XPath/XQuery Builder
    • For example to search for a bracket withing the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(")] The "(" at the end is what determines the bracket. Enter this into the XPath/XQuery Builder and press the play button to perform the search.
    • To find an opening square bracket in the glossary use the following code: //gloss/term[@xml:lang = 'Bo-Ltn'][contains(text(), "(") or contains(text(), "[")]
    • By using backslashes and element names you can also look for specific terms within particular elements, for example to search for a certain "word" within the <note> elements, you could use this code: //note[contains(data(), 'word')] Here 'word' is what you are looking for. // means search everywhere, //note means search everywhere for <note>s.
    • You can save your search codes for later by clicking on the star icon.
    • To learn more about XPath syntax and how it works. There is a good tutorial here.
    • Also this section of the tutorial here, explains some syntax, which you should be able to use with the XPath/XQuery Builder.
  • XPath Codes
    • Find footnote by index (e.g. 12): //note[@xml:id eq //*:end-note[@index eq '12']/@id]
    • Find glossary by index (e.g. 12): //gloss[@xml:id eq //*:gloss[@index eq '12']/@id]
    • Find Sanskrit string length 15 or more: //*[string-length(string()) > 14 and @xml:lang ='Sa-Ltn']
  • Searching through the Text
    • You may notice that when you search for certain phrases in the XML, the phrase may not be found in the "Find/Replace" dialog. This is because the search tool is very precise so it will not find phrases with two or more words that are separated by a line break unless you specify it to do so. One way around this is to use the "Find in files" (click the second smaller magnifying glass in the ribbon or CTRL/SHIFT/H). Then select "All opened files" (It will ask you to save before it searches) and make sure "Ignore white spaces" is checked ("Regular expressions" must be unchecked for it to work). It will then ignore the line breaks.
    • The method above doesn't work with regular expressions. If you need to search in this way with regular expressions, then try replacing the spaces in your code with: \s+, e.g. search "door of dharma" with "door\s+of\s+dharma"
    • On occasion you may want to search the XML while ignoring all the tags. To do this, again use "find in files" CTRL/Shift/H and in the field that says "Restrict to XPath;" enter the code //text()
    • This will ignore the tags in your search results. Note, it will ignore the tags but it can't search over tags if a tag appears in the middle of a searched phrase, so for instance it won't fine "vidy being" in the XML for
      <term>vidy</term> being

Appendix K Guidelines for Updating Versions of the TEI Document

Version Numbering:

The three digit version numbering (e.g., "v 1.2.1") we are using here refer respectively to "major", "minor", and "revision" changes to the text (This emulates software versioning standards).

Any changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual updates that don't substantially affect the text (typos, minor markup/formatting consistencies, etc.). A change from 1.2.1 to 1.2.2 signals to the reader that there is no need to download it. Any change in the second decimal relates to a minor, but more significant changes within the text itself as well as to significant markup changes. For example, a missing stanza has been added, or a misspelled term has been corrected throughout the text. A change from 1.2.1 to 1.3.0 indicates that readers should download the latest version to have an improved version of the text. Any change in the first decimal would be a major change to the text, so 1.3.1 to 2.0.0. would be a clear sign that it should be downloaded.

To summarize:

  • Changes in the third decimal relate to very minor textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.3.5
  • Changes in the second decimal relate to minor, but more significant textual and markup changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 1.4.0
  • Changes in first decimal relate to major text changes, e.g., 1.3.4 to 2.0.0
Text Numbering Workflow

Most texts that have not been started in the translation process have no version number. When a text receives its first update it will change to

0.0.1

When markup is started, the text gets an initial version number:

0.1.1

From that point on, version numbers will increase every time editors feel its necessary as they work on the text. As noted before, changes made to the second decimal point are reserved for more significant textual and markup edits, and changes made to the third decimal point are reserved for minor textual and markup edits. Theoretically, a text could go through many versions before it is ready for publication, eg

0.0.1 to 0.0.2

0.0.2 to 0.1.0

0.1.0 to 0.1.1 etc

When the text is ready for publication then the version number is set by the markup editor to

1.0.0

When updating the TEI to a published translation please use the following procedure:
  • (1) Save your changes from Oxygen.
  • (2) If you changed any of the markup, run the automated tests on the individual file by clicking on "run tests" next to the text title from the Utilities page (Note: don't run the automated tests from the "tests" tab unless it is necessary to check all the texts, as this will uses up a lot of the server's resources). Correct any issues related to failing test results or inform tech (Dom) about any test updates that may be needed.
  • (3) Finally, after saving the TEI from Oxygen, the version number needs to be updated separately on the project management page. This is important to keep track of any changes we've made to the published text: From the project management page, find the text according to its "text status," then click on "edit headers." From here, update both the version number (as described in the guidelines above) and if necessary the version's date (entering for the date only a four digit year, e.g., "2019"). Note, the "Publication Date" refers to the date of the original publication, so please leave this unchanged. Please also add a brief note in the "Add a note about this version" field about what changes were made. Now, click the "Update" button. Updating the version number in this way will simultaneously update the <editionStmt>'s version and date within the TEI file, upload the latest version to the Github repository, and generate the newest version of the eBook and PDF (this last part of the update only occurs if it is status="1").
  • (4) Note that unless the change is urgent, you do not need to push the file to distribution. This will be handled in a weekly check by the revision lead (Martina).

Note that there is a delay when pushing to distribution. It sometimes takes 6-8 hours to see changes updated. If you want to assure that the changes will be made change the URL on distribution from "...read" to "...direct-read" e.g.: change "https://read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html" to "https://direct-read.84000.co/translation/toh83.html". This will show you the pending updates.


Global Changes:

Occasionally, global changes will need to be made for all the texts, usually performed with a script or a search-and-replace in the translations folder (By the way if you make global search-and-replaces to a folder be sure that Oxygen's "Make back of files with extension" box is unchecked, as this will cause problems in the database). Since it would be time consuming to update each text manually, please follow this protocol for updating the texts manually:

  • 1.) Make the global change (using script or find and replace). Make sure that the operation has worked correctly.
  • 2.) Ask tech (Dominic) to run a script to update version numbers and add a descriptive note.
  • 3.) Take a snapshot to capture version history for git (This is on the Utilities page menu: "Make a Data Snapshot").
  • 4.) Assess whether pdfs, epubs, and html need to be republished immediately. If so, then do it manually using utilities. If not, then wait for the next change that warrants a republishing of the text. Especially minor changes may not warrant updating all the publications as texts will be updated periodically, and the change will be added eventually.

Whenever you make changes to a published text, you should always change the version number from project management. When you start working on a text in markup use a version number beginning with 0.1.1. Generally, we don't need a versioning history while the text is in the markup process, however, if the markup for a text is particularly complex, e.g., it is a very large text, it includes attributes that require us to come up with new markup language, it includes a complex outline structure, etc., you should occasionally update the version (e.g., 0.1.2) from project management as you processes different stages of the markup. In such cases, it would also be a good idea to occasionally save a backup locally to your computer. This way we can track the text, and especially have a way of knowing what version it is in case something goes wrong (which does happen from time to time).

Appendix L Guidelines for Checking Older Versions of the TEI Documents in the Github Repository:

Sometimes there may have been an edition or correction that was made in an earlier version of a TEI file that was made in error or for some other reason we need to check that changes that were made in an earlier version of a document. In such cases, all the older versions of the XML are saved as snapshots in 84000's Github repository. To check older versions of the TEI please follow these steps below:

Read or Download Archived Files on Github
  • Go to the translations folder on 84000's Github repository using this link. You do not need a Github account to check the version history.
  • From there you will be able to navigate to the TEI file you need. The repository should have the same outline and structure as the TEI database we work from on Oxygen.
  • Once you navigated to the file you need click on the "History" button. This will take you to a new screen showing you a history of all the snapshots of the file, called "commits" on Github.
  • By clicking on each commit, it will show you all the additions and deletions that were made to the file at that time. The version number update should be close to the top of the page. From here, it is very convenient to see what changes have been made to the file for each version update.
  • Or you can simply download that version of the TEI file by first clicking on the three dots ... to the right of the file name of that version, click "view file", the new screen click on the "download" button. (Note that some browsers will just open the XML on a new page, so you might need to right-click "Save Link As..." to download the actual file.

All the older versions of the files should be here since the time we begin syncing this Github repository. Note that sometimes there may have been a few version updates before a commit, but there should be a record of all the differences between the version at the time of the commit and the previous one.

View Archived TEI in the Reading Room Display
  • If needed, it is also possible to see how older versions of the TEI display in the Reading Room. First download the desired version of the TEI from Github following the instructions above.
  • From the database explorer go to the folder in Collaboration/db/apps/84000-data/archived/tei/reference, then right click on the folder and select "import files." Select the file from your computer that you downloaded from Github.
  • The following URL, with the Toh number entered into the TohXXX will load the archived file to the Reading Room on Collaboration: https://read.84000-translate.org/translation/tohXXX.html?archive-path=tei/reference
  • The suffix "?archive-path=tei/reference" will likely work with some of the other formats as well.
  • Note, there is currently an issue with this method; it doesn't work for Toh numbers's with a dash, e.g., "1-1"

There may also be some versions of antiquated formats in the repository, so if you don't see what you are looking for in the translations folder, you can also search in the main branch.

Appendix M Reporting Typos or Errors in the eKangyur:

The eKangyur is typically very precise, but occasionally there may have been an error when they were inputting the text. If you suspect a typo in the eKangyur, please note it in the spread sheet here. This should not include errors in the original block print, which we will leave as is, but there may have been an error in the text input of the eKangyur from the original scanned source. The source of the eKangyur is the scanned LoC edition on tbrc.org, W4CZ5369 (Although it follows the volume order of W22084, the Parphud edition on tbrc.org). Occasionally the print may be illegible due to smudges, and so you may compare with W22084, which as far as I know is nearly identical. Of course, it not really our job to proof read the eKangyur, so don't spend hours checking for typos in the eKangyur; but you may happen to notice an error now and then while checking the source, and in such case you can enter them into the spreadsheet and they can be reported to Esukhia at some point.

Appendix N Learning TEI/XML

If you are learning TEI or XML from the beginning, or would like to review some of that training, here are some useful places to begin:

  • What is the TEI? And why should I care? (A brief introduction for classicists)

    This is an introductory slide show explaining what TEI is.

  • An Introduction to XML

    This is a basic introduction to XML.

  • TEI by Example

    This a tutorial along with interactive examples and tests. This is a good place to begin if you are just getting started.

  • The TEI Guidelines

    This is the official manual on TEI and a good place to look up references, as it has all the standards in one place.

  • TEI's Github, Issues Section

    This is the TEI forum for the general TEI community. After you have some experience working with TEI, this is a good place to go for any troubleshooting or issues.

  • More Tips for Oxygen XML Editor

    Here is a short video for 84000 Markup Editors showing a few tips and tricks for using the Oxygen XML Editor.
